reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing this game and watching it develop for a while now. It has been a delightful experience. The game is progressing beautifully. The small team of developers are responsive and update the game regularly and I have no complaints or regrets about backing this unique game.

I say unique deliberately. I often look through the Steam lists for games like this (because I enjoy this kind of thing) but I can honestly say I have found nothing to compare with Folk Tale's general standard of excellence and with this developers dedication and refusal to compromise on excellence. Even though it's not yet finished there is still a reasonable amount of content and more being added all the time.

Let me also mention the editing tools that come with the game and are improving all the time. I have almost 900 hours on this game and the vast majority of that time has been spent using the Editor. There will be a keen group of Workshop map makers who will gaurantee the longevity of Folk Tale so we need never run out of content.

Yes, I have seen some of the negative reviews and frankly most of them are simply garbage. They certainly don't represent the game I know. Everyone is entitled to their opinion of course but I suspect that some of the negative reviews have simply nothing to do with rational opinion. At least, that's my opinion.

Great game, great future, not finished yet but getting there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overview:
Stronghold 2 got herself pregnant, the father? She can’t decide if Warcraft 3, The Settlers, or Banished is the father, and she is only in the first trimester so it’s impossible to tell currently, but she does have a name already picked out for the child; Folk Tale.

Early Access:
Currently this game is in early access. Why is this important to say when that should be obvious? Because there are those, ah hell who am I kidding, MOST “gamers” don’t know what the hell that means apparently.  Early access games can take six months, they can take five years, they might never be finished; picture it is like a kick starter but the dev is nice enough to give you free copies of their beta’s and alpha’s as they build the game. This is not a completed game and it may never be a completed game. A dev company can promise to “complete said game” but that is all it is, a promise, there is nothing legally speaking they have to do other than slap a “1.0” sticker on the game (Craft the World) and walk away. People need to know that and understand that going into any EA game.

The Game Vision
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EzDTbp4aXX8

The Game Currently (May 13th):
Currently the game has a tutorial and basically what I would describe as “Beta Maps”, four of them, which take anywhere from five to ten hours each to really enjoy. That means you are talking about twenty to forty hours of gameplay if you just gave each of their maps a real shot. Don’t look at “how many hours” people have put into the game, many have put far more hours into the game than it says on Steam as for some reason the hours are just not clicking over correctly (offline mode possibly?).

The three more sandbox style maps (Easily labeled on the side as easy/medium/hard) basically are set up just like most RTS games, you have a couple villagers and some supplies and build from there. Unlike most RTS games however (Other than Banished for some reason… for the life of me I don’t know why that game gets the reviews it does) Folk Tale currently does not have an “endgame”, ie. killing the enemy base, completing the mission, etc. Basically you build you city, survive and run amok as long as you desire/ can survive (ie. Banished) and that is that.

Anyone who has played the Stronghold games will find this game strangely familiar, even the voice acting. The same style of walls, buildings, humor, villagers are not produced they just “appear” if you have the houses to support them and the happiness to attract them, etc. If I were to sum up the game currently I would say it is 50% Stronghold (Economy/Buildings/ Defensive Structures/Audio/Troops), 25% Settlers 7 (Economy Chains/Buildings/Villigers), 20% Warcraft 3 (Fantasy world/Combat), and 5% Banished (Possible sandbox?). (That’s a 100% right? Good…) If they threw together a random map generator and multiplied the map size by at least 3x this game would dwarf Banished in its content alone.

The combat is vastly different from Stronghold, in favor of what I see as the developers taking a page from Warcraft 3. Instead of vast, vast armies you now command a smaller crew (with heroes in the works) that can all be personally equipped with gear and upgraded as they level up. I am assuming they will have a “Hall of Heroes” style building like Warcraft to bring your heroes back from the grave- hasn’t been implemented yet.

The Problem:
It is so hard to understand the minds and predict the mood swings of gamers today, I would dare say it might be impossible, and at the very least it is clearly the most difficult time I can recall- and I have been in gaming a long time. Call me sexiest if you must but when did gamers start acting like a bunch of girls thinking with their woman parts more than with their brains? Basically all you have now are angry fan boi’s- I know, I get in trouble for bringing this up over and over again, but it is just sadly the truth!- and all they do is evaluate a game or a developer emotionally and then damn the facts. This game is absolutely no different. You have a group of people who didn’t like “not getting their way” in a vote that happened apparently years ago and because of that one event and how it made them “feel” they grouped up and went to war, the game itself be damned “I just don’t like the fact I didn’t get 100% of my way when I contributed a drop in that bucket!” Looking at the facts, logically, with a clear mind, I ask “how could any developer making a game in early access please every single person who signs on and supports them in early access?” and then I ask “how would you make sure that the majority of what your early access contributors are asking for, you are providing?” and I dare say that you will not come up with a better solution than what this developer did- vote and follow the vote. So looking at this logically, with your head, I ask “why hurt much?”

Why do “gamers” now go through reviews and upvote and downvote purely off of if they recommended or did not recommend, the review itself be damned? Why do “gamers” now overlook countless flaws, countless bugs, countless AI failures, pay to play/win/continue features in a game purely because “the developer… giggle*, is my friend!” (God, I am looking at you Banished/Creativerse) while at the same time these same “gamers” take dumps on games that have more content, less bugs, better AI, and no pay to play/win/continue features in their game just because something or someone “rubbed them the wrong way”? The problem? Gamers need to start putting the game first (Thank you Divinity Original Sin) and put their emotions in their purses, loyalty to a developing company be damned! (Who is Larian Studios anyways?)

Bottom Line:
So basically if you think you would enjoy a game that would have the combat and fantasy style world like that of Warcraft 3 while having the economy and base building of a Stronghold then I would strongly recommend supporting this game as I have not seen anything similar in years (Warcraft 4 is basically every modern day MOBA, no thanks, and the new Stronghold was a step back in every sense of “step back”) and I don’t know when or if you’ll see anymore. I have played AAA titles that were not as fined tuned as this game currently is, and those games have sold for over $50. The developers of Folk Tale are claiming that they are still a long ways off from where they want to end up- that should impress and scare most of us.

If you would like to see my thoughts on other games or movies check out my blog which you can find in my Steam profile or by google, search Ashley and Micah English. Thanks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game in a class on its own. It combines city building and rpg and provides the oppurtunity for players to create their own worlds to share with the community. Although still in development when completed this game will have something for everyone.

I would recommend this game to anyone that:

*Understands that the game will be released in 2016 so that they may need to wait a year. If you havent purchased the game yet then reading all those reviews complaining that its 2 years in early access arent really relevant to you because you dont have to wait 2 years.

*Consider $25 isnt such a large financial expenditure that they will always be complaining how they could have better spent it and wishing they hadnt spent it

*Are interested geniunely interested in the games development that they watch the weekly dev hangouts on twitch or youtube and contribute their ideas and suggestions in the forum.

*Is willing to do their own reserch about the game to see if its for them. Research can include watching game play online. Going to the developers website and reading all the detail looking at the road map etc

The developers are honest and very polite and are present daily on the forums answering all questions even questions that have been asked a million times before.

I havent regretted my purchase and have managed to get more than 80 hours out of this game. I watch the dev hangouts every week once posted on youtube and check the forum regulary for changes tips and suggestions.

I understand that to develop a game on this level takes time and this developer doesnt want to sacrifice quality just to release it quickly to appease those who complain about the time in development.

If you want to buy but have doubts then hold off until you feel this is something that you want to buy or until wait until release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game in early access is without any doubt in my mind absolutely brilliant.

Ok, now that's out of the way, the tutorial that comes with the game is fully playable and very good, but it's not what the games about. It's about a lot, lot more than that.

It is now a sandbox game, we have an editor to design our own  levels to share with the community and eventually portals to join them together to make complete worlds, we already have Grasslands, swamps , snow zone and more on the way, the models, animations and artwork are amazing.

I could go on at length (but I won't ) If you have a little patience then buying it will be worthwhile or wait a couple of months and look at it again, but to me it's alread worth the price tag.

They are only a small team producing outstanding work, given the time (and the support), they will produce a brilliant piece of software.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just a very brief review.

The game in general is progressing nicely, with an excellent citybuilding element already present. The second component of the game, the RPG element, is in its early stages of implementation. So expect to see more on this soon! From what I've seen so far, and what is to come, I would recommend purchesing this game!

Rather than discuss the positive aspects of the game, as many have already done, the thing I'm mainly overwhelmingly happy about is the engagement with the player and supporter base. Monthly patches, twitch streams, regular blog updates and just prompt and effective communication on the forum are just some examples. On that note alone, if you are into the citybuilding/RPG genre of games and crave involvement with the creative process (mainly through feedback), I strongly recommend this game.

All in all, this has been the best experience I have had from an early access game!

Early Access Review

I've been following the development of this game more or less closely and I am impressed - not only with the progress gamesfoundry made but also with the courage with which they took on the challenge to transform the early average concept into a sandbox game highly demanded by the community.
Of course this is a rocky and never straight path, but seeing what they have achieved in the last year I am confident this will be one gem of game once it is finished, which it isn't yet and most likely will not be for some time.
One has to understand, that this is a huge undertaking for such a small company. So I fyou expect something playable and want to start building your little own world right now, I suggest you wait and watch a bit longer.
However if you want to be part of the process and you know what developing games is about, I really recommend diving into it: the editor, the sandbox player and the community. Give your feedback and help making this project a success. Given the very moderate pricetag this is almost no risk compared to prepurchasing one of the much more expensive Titles that don't give a wellyouknow about how you want to play a game.

I'm not in anyway related to the gamesfoundry. I just bought this a while ago and I love watching the progress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Got the game today, have been keeping it on my Wishlist for over a year.
Haven't watched much before, didn't know too much about it at the moment of purchase.

In short, if you like the Settlers franchise then this game wants to be in a similar category. Of course with some Warcraft (not World of Warcraft) RTS elements, such as champions, fighting, loot, etc.
But the economy" is similar to what Settlers is.

PROs:
- Inspired by Settlers (probably)
- Smooth building mode
- Interesting "tree" of buildings and upgrades
- The start phase of a new game is much more enjoyable than it looks like.

CONs:
- Sandbox has 3 levels of difficulty
recommended:
so only 3 maps. You can't just start a game with a different layout and try to build it out. You always know the exact starting location. That's boring. Personally I think that a simulator like this needs a random map generator.
- In Sandbox mode you need about ~30-45 minutes to have all the buildings and some of the important upgrades. After that there's not much to do.
- Some people complain about the rate of updates.

I have 5.6 hours on this
hoursPlayed: that's 2 sandbox games (unfinished
voteText:
there are no victory conditions).
Was it enjoyable? Yes.
Does the game feel like a good product? Yes.
Does it have great potential? Yes.
Would I recommend buying it now? No."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never really cared enough to post a review of a game, this is my first. It bothers me that people give this game poor reviews. It's an Early Access game!! There will be bugs! I'm sorry, but you're an idiot if you purchase an Early Access game and expect it to run perfectly.

First and foremost, Folk Tale is (and will be) brilliant! It is exactly what I've been wishing for in a game. At the moment it's more or less just a city builder like Banished, except it will be so very much more when complete.

The realm is rich with detail, the humor edgy. It's been fun to watch this game come to life throughout the entire process. This game has so much potential it's hard to be patient while waiting for it to be complete. I've been hooked since I first purchased it, which was BEFORE any save was available.

The developers are much more transparent than any other EA games I have purchased, keeping us up to date on what is on task, sharing artwork for new features/characters/buildings etc that will be implemented in future patches. I don't know what the final price will be upon completion but I've definitely gotten my money's worth out of what exists right now.
If you're considering this game, ignore the haters. Most didn't even take the time to read the discussions or the Folk Tale blog. If they had, they woudln't have been wanking about half of the things they were.

IT IS WORTH THE MONEY, because the price will only go up as it gets better. Buy now, support devs who care more about you than about pre-sales and enjoy watching a game as it develops; especially getting to be a part of having a voice in the development of this game.

I definantly recommend this game to any and all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really enjoy this game.
It combines some of my favorite gaming genres and elements - a singleplayer citybuilder game with crafting and economy combined with loot and level elements.

At this point the game is not complete and there are some obvious bugs that I'm sure they will fix eventually (can't trash items from you limited inventory, sometimes enemies are invulnerable for a short while, etc.).
However: the game get's a bit monotonous once you have established a town that can survive the attacking monsters.  There is however talk about (re)implementing a quest system and maybe even a campaign, which would really awesome.

Despite this, I think it is a great game and if you like me enjoy citybuilder games and loot'n level games I think this game will be worth your time. I really look forward to any further development :)

Cheers

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It seems to me a lot of the negative reviews posted here are from people who are misinformed or just plain impatient. The devs of this game asked the community about a year ago if they preferred a sandbox or campaign mode. Most of the community chose sandbox so the entire game has been re-written the last year to acomplish that. We were told it would take awhile and now the foundation is complete so there will be updates more regularly. How many game developers do you know that will re-write the programming on a game they are developing to meet the wants of the community?  The devs of this game stay in constant contact with us on the forums and have not once failed to meet a promise they have made. Developement was slow at first but now is speeding up since the foundation is complete. This game IS worth your time and money. While its not near completion just yet it is getting there at a steady pace now. I personally have bought games on steam that the devs don't keep the community updated or leave the game broken and basically give up. If your one of those players who have had a similar experience  I can asure you that this game is different.
In fact I can promise you this is the most active development team I have ever seen in an early access game. Please Help support Games Foundry and buy this game. It will be an investment well spent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

They've still got a ways to go in development, but the game is GORGEOUS.  I guess you have to like the lighthearted style; but for me, it's actually the game I've always dreamed of!

Cartoony; humorous; deep citybuilding economy; full freedom of camera(you can look up at the horizon); full micro of each and every one of your citizen's gear/posessions; non-instant building placement; pre-gunpowder-tech combat; huge(ish) environments; a campaign story with character role-play elements; Eyefinity friendliness; I could keep going.  I LOVE THIS GAME!

If you're a conservative buyer, at least track it's development; as there isn't MUCH gameplay yet; but with every patch(roughly monthly), they add a little more to the economic chain, and there is combat and level editing coming along nicely, also.

Every(?) Sunday the main dev gets on twitch to show off the progress they're making that week, and just hang out with the fans.  This is one of the games that truly show that the publisher model is being pushed aside, and we're really starting to see a true renaissance in gaming.  If that's your bag, pick this game up only to help assure this funding model stays around; and let this game see the light of day.

TLDR:  Buy it.  It's good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to take a moment to comment on 'Folk Tale'.  I have been watching since it first appeared and became extremely interested in it after watching some videos and visiting the developers' website.  I wrote a comment before I purchased the game and then waited til it was playable to buy it.

Folk Tale is an immersive City Builder type game,  but with a twist of RPG and some of the real-time civ games I've played.  I really like the game overall.  It has great graphics (which are not my main point of interest), a deep building system and plenty to do while you're waiting on new villagers to arrive.  You can craft, battle, follow a guy or gal around and watch them work, lash the workers into a working frenzy, and even research upgrades on each of the buildings you've created.

I cannot end this comment, however, without bringing to attention a few bugs I noticed in the most recent update--the experimental build which came out on Saturday.  First off, before this latest version, the battle system worked flawlessly, but now, I notice that not even Sir Gregory can damage the foes (like the goblins outside of the human woodland area or even the bandits at the beginning of the campaign).  This makes the campaign-mode unplayable again and further makes it lose some of its greatness in the sandbox mode.  I would recommend that the developers take the time to fix whatever could be causing the issue at once and then release another update (so I can kill things again!)   Also, the new happiness system is pretty cool.  It is MUCH BETTER than the old repeated warning about food supplies being low and such.  The only thing is, with the happiness system implemented, it is difficult (nearly impossible) to keep folks happy at the beginning of the game.  By the time you build a farm, a fishery and send a person off to gather up berries, the people are already leaving because of low food supplies.  I would say the easiest fix to this problem would be to change the amount of food each villager eats when they are hungry.  I know you can alter the 'rations' meter, but it just isn't enough to keep folks around.  Besides, making them eat less than they want to automatically makes them mad.  I even went as far as to give them extra amounts of firewood to offset the issue, but I could never draw in the new villagers I needed to make the town continue to grow.

Anyway, I really love the game and will continue to watch for updates.  You guys are building a dynamic game here.  I know there are nay-sayers, but I think it's coming along well enough and offers quite a bit of humourous detail to offset the small downsides to the project.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a hallmark of what gaming should be.
Not because the game is beautiful (which it is), or funny (which it is), or has engaging gameplay, depth and charme (which it does). The true strength of this title, that sets it apart of the rest, is the developer.

I have never (and might never again) spend money on an unfinished title, but this time I had to do it, simply because the developer is in constant, open, honest and fair contact with everyone who wishes to engage them. They treat people like humans, not wallets. Every week, the boss himself (whom we all who usually tune in just call Simon) streams for hours, talking with viewers about the game, taking suggestions and criticism, offering insight in their vision, or just chatting about kinds of toast.

As you can tell, I WANT this title to succeed. It's an ambitious, inspired work by ambitious, likeable people.
If you don't believe me, do yourself a favor and come by the streams or write in the forums sometime, and see for yourself.

As for the actual content ingame, it has grown tremendously in the last months. I won't go into too much detail as the game is A. still in Early Acces and stuff will evolve and B. because you can read all about that on their homepage anyway.
As jaded and critical as I am, I believe in the end product of Folk Tale.

TLDR: The negative reviews on here are outdated and misguided, the game is alot of fun and has an awesome, unique charme, and the developer is absolutely worth supporting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been hungering for a game like this. A city management/rpg hybrid. Like if Banished and Warcraft had a lovechild.
The game is in early access still, but so far plays pretty well. I love the overall aesthetic, and light-hearted approach to this. You're not going to find anything groundbreaking in terms of mythos. We have standard heroes, civilians, and creatures like orcs/wolves/spiders etc, here. But the originality lies in the merging of genres. I think it was clever to not break too many molds here: the familiarity makes the game accessible.

I have encountered a game breaking bug, that seems to happen at random - is being ignored at the moment (unsure why. my guess is priorities)

DO NOT LET THE MIXED" REVIEW PURSUADE YOU
the negative reviews are based on issues that have long since been addressed and are no longer existent in the game.

should you buy it? YES. This game is already solid and the devs have all but proven they're committed to the cause. This is a wonderful merging of genres that hasn't seen the light of day since "Warlords: Battlecry" (released 15 years ago)

Pros:
+easy to learn
+great merging of genres
+addictive and entertaining
+your town IS able to become self-sufficient! (this is huge! and I hope they don't remove it. it's nice to be able to let your town go about it's business while you're off adventuring)
+regularly updated

Cons:
-still in development (which is clearly stated but that still means it's incomplete)
-once you've built everything
recommended: and cleared the map of chests
hoursPlayed:
there's not a whole heck of a lot to do (see: my suggestions)
-the occassional bug
-lack of depth in leveling your hero

UPDATE: I have about 8hrs of game time already

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I purchased this game in May 2015, and have followed its progress each week. This is an updated review from the one I wrote shortly after that.

One thing I must say: The development progresses constantly, with what appears to be a goal of polishing as it gets done. Nice work!

Positive
- It has a full editor to make lots of worlds, and dungeons that you can play in, or share online for others to play too!
- There are 100's of free items to build with to make amazing looking worlds or dungeons
- The game looks really polished and reminds me of Fable, with its hand painted artwork approach
- If you play the tutorial, it is like a 3D version of a city management game, with crafting and building upgrades etc
- You can move the camera anywhere in 3D, even following the peasants and workers around the village.
- The game has been balanced, and is enjoyable to play.

Negative
- There is steady progress in the development, but it might appear that features are not moving along in strides.

Summary
Buy the game. I did. Why? To give this producer/coder, and his army of artists and other helpers, a bit of cash to hopefully in some years, get to a point beyond alpha. He has a great idea, and the helpers are doing what they can to support him. With a bit more cash, they might succeed and I really hope they do.

Also, if you buy the game, you get the sandbox tools (which is built into the game) for free, with 100s of items to build with and decorate your dungeons or landscapes. There is also an included visual script tool to make spawns, and quests and NPC dialogues. Its like a free game maker even inside this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sadly i have to agree with most of the posts afore,

while i am still excited about the concept, the game in its current state hardly deserves the title. A lot is drafted, but nothing is fleshed out. The game has good graphics and an immersive soundtrack. Other than that, there is not a lot to play with. Most of the production chains are useless. There is only one tier of armor, that merits the effort of making. None of the weapons are. While there are three diferent food production chains, which are not optional btw, you cannot really get a grasp of where you are standing with either of them. The hero is weaker than any basic arbalist (arbalists beeing the only military unit that do any good, having the ability to carry worthwhile armor).

Basic mechanics, such as an hidden inventory slot for production and recruiting buildings are missing. This says a lot about the production value. The GUI as well.

As a summary i must sadly say, the game provides only a few hours of gameplay. One hour for the town and maybe three to get some walls around, since the mobs constantly respawn, basically the only way to get some peace for your settlers.

I hope my review saves others the 20 EUR i spent, and is not regarded as an angry review. I play games for more than twenty years and i concern myself with quality and project management for a living.

@Devs: If you are willing to fill the games basic mechanics with life, which would be probably an undertaking of mere hours, i am sure you will get better reviews. Rather than putting effort in the misleading advertisements, reconsider what is needed to move the project along.

9/10 for the idea and concept
2/10 for realisation

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFirst off let me say that this game is in Early Access and has the potential to change over time from what my review is saying (6/2/2014). This game is by far one of my most highly praised games among all of the ones I own. I personally do not rate games highly unless they either have great potential and are living up to the expectation, or delivered on exactly what I desired and sometimes more. This game while in early form, has a great location editor and sandbox foundation, as well as the development team is transparent with the community giving us updates on the game's status and what we can expect. While many people rated this game down, it has come a long way from what it used to be, with more frequent updates, blogs, and responses to the community. I have never had to wait longer than 3 hours when I posted in the forum asking a question or making some form of a comment. This game has been delivering on everything they promised and continue to listen to the community. I would highly suggest this game if you are even remotely interested by what their vision for the outcome is!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAbout a year ago I gave this game a review that did not reccomend it, my reasoning was I felt the story had been abandoned for an open world sandbox game that had not been the intention of the game at the time. However because this should be about whether or not I reccomend the game to new buyers I've decided to change my original review to a positve one. Folk Tale now has a very clear goal in it's continued development as an early access game. With an art style remeniscent of Fable and gameplay like that of Black and White it's good fun to play for a few hours at a time making use of each new update and keeping track of the development bloggs. If your new to the game you'll know what they are offering you from the trailers and enjoy it for those reasons. Whilst I hope that when the game is finished it will have a full story mode that still holds all the great humour that I enjyed two years ago.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having watched this game for a while, I boticed that the reviews had taken an upswing recently, so finally purchased. Whilst it is an entertaining game with some very lofty ideals and far-reaching concepts, many of these have either not been fully implemented yet, or they need a lot of polish and balancing. But even as it stands, the game is playable and enjoyable, albeit frustrating at times. Yes, it has been EA for a long time, but this is a game slowly forming and maturing and can only improve with the more interest and input and backing it receives. I do recommend this game to others, but the biggest negatives thus far:

* No in-game pause. There is a lot to do in the game, but it all has to be done in real time, and many of the micromanagement elements (talked about later) are left undone as you rush around, trying to keep everything going, especially in the early game. You can stop the game by opening the settings menu, but you're unable to do anything
* Combat is very unformed. Without the pause function to regroup and refocus troops, you often find yourself throwing everything you can at enemies, with your heroes lost in the very early game, with no way (that I've so far found) to revive or replace them. Enemies also tend to wander in a little too often at times, often undoing lots of hard work.
* Building placement and world interaction is pretty basic. Building placement is touchy (to say the least), with every building requiring quite a bit of space, or just refusing to go into places you would excpect it to go. So far, there's also no way to remove or add any in-world items beyong buildings, either. This results in a wide spread of buildings placed down with little thought, just wherever they'll fit; and with no roads and no decorations, there is little visual cohesion to help turn it into a real town.
*Micromanagement needs to be dropped or nerfed until it's more fully-formed. The RPG elements of leveling up, making and finding better equipment, researching new things for buildings is great, but there's so much to do and precious little time. Did I mention there's no workable pause yet? Pretty sure I did. Defeating a group of enemies can result in some little bits of armor that your workers can use, or you can begin crafting armor and weapons for troops and workers, but these have to be handed out individually, piece by piece, a tedious process you quickly tire of. There seems to be no way to queue research for buildings and upgrading buildings can be a really expensive option for (at the moment) little gain in many cases.

It sounds bad, I know, but I do recommend this game. It's playable, it's enjoyable and it is slowly coming together. Many other people have complained about the lack of a serious campaign so far, but, for my tastes, I would much rather they focus on getting the city-building and micromanagement elements streamlined and rock-solid, then they can begin to flesh out campaigns and really bring the RPG elements to life. There's so much potential here and the developers are moving in the right direction. I just hope they don't lose faith in the game before it's done.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm having a lot of fun with the game. The graphics are so cool, and the way the people go about their business...I just love watching them. Then you have the exploration with the hero side of it. That just adds more fun things to do. Quests, dungeons, fighting off intruders, etc.

If you're on the fence, I will tell you that I definitely don't regret the purchase. If it takes a long time to add even more awesome features to the game, I hope they do it. It will just up the replayability value, in my opinion.

The game is completely playable from what I've seen, and I've played it for almost 4 hours straight with no bugs, glitches, DCs, or weirdness at all. I was playing the campaign mode, mainly building and killing stuff all over the map.

I love these kinds of games, building a town from the ground up and managing resources, keeping the people happy, and defending your settlement. With the hero RPG aspect thrown in, it's even more interesting. I've played many city builders, and I have to say that this is my new favorite.

Highly recommended. It's on sale at the time of this writing, so pick it up and enjoy. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game for quite some time with cautious enthusiasm and finally made the plunge and purchased the game a few days ago.  You can see an in depth play through and review at:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC8Rq0jnAyAkf1zjDhP60ARA

Key Highlights:

1.  It is obvious this is game is made by a Dev team that is passionate about the project and is looking to provide as polished and fulfilling experience as they can.    There are still some kinks to be worked out, but I can state that iat this point in the Early Access process the game provides a value that matches its cost.

2.  The Dev team has an easy to read/understand development timeline, and to date they have proven they can be trusted to follow through.

3.  'As' is the game is fun, a nice  little way to spend a few casual afternoons, and certainly worth its price point.  A plethora of less passionate Early Access Dev's exist that would put a bow on this and be able to ethically call it complete.   I really look forward to seeing what can become of this project with this development team who seem to have the old Blizzard' mindset of "It will be released when it’s done."

Bottom line:  Already fun to play
date: and has the potential to be an all-time great if the development plan is executed as briefed (it has been

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Folk Tale is an Early Access game in Alpha Development by Games Foundry Limited.  It is a Sandbox mode City Builder which includes combat, events and will have quests and adventurers.  It will include not only the traditional city building but strategy and role playing elements.The Location editor is currently available for those who enjoying making maps and they can be uploaded on the forum for others to play.  The World Editor will be added in the future making it possible to connect up different maps for questing.  These are the same tools the developers use for making their maps and is well supported by Games Foundry.
There are bugs and glitches which is to be expected in alpha development.  Community supporters help with testing and making suggestions.  I find being part of this process great fun and a good learning experience.
The save/load feature is not officially enabled but there is one available through the console

People often post on the forum asking whether they should buy or not.  I recommend this game to anyone who  enjoys city building in an open world with free play.  It is still in the early stage of development and game play is limited.  Each patch which comes out monthly adds to the game play.  Games Foundry provides monthly  blogs on the progress of the game and the developers are very responsive to the community answering questions and suggestions.

For information regarding the progress of the game please check out the developers' Roadmap.  Here is the link:
http://www.gamesfoundry.com/roadmap.aspx

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Was excited to see what the Devs and artists had done for this game so got myself a early access release.
Bugs are minor, and the community seems to be giving feedback as and when issues occur.
While the game mode is still largely unplayable at the time of writing (in that there's not a hell of a lot to do or any clear goals), I've enjoyed the tutorial levels and little bit of messing around I've done so far.
Art style and storytelling is incredibly charming and gives one a sense of nostalgia for world builders of old. So far the difficulty curve seems rather steep, but I don't think its fair to make any comments on actual game play until this game is complete - which looks to be a long way off.
Looking forward to playing this once the scenerios and game is complete and would recommend people giving it a play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is early access and far from completed so bear that in mind when deciding to buy it.

However it has a lot of potential, mixing RPG elements with RTS gameplay. The tutorial is very fun but hasn't been updated in ages, all the work has gone into sandbox mode where one finds the latest updates to the game content and gameplay wise. Visually it looks stunning.

The game isn't really playable right now from my point of view, you can do most stuff you'd expect but there is no way to win sandbox maps for instance as enemies simply respawn.

What works: building stuff, putting villagers to work, combat, equiping units, some economic chains, crafting

Not done yet: saving the game, unit stats, food consumption, disease, balance


I don't regret my purchase, the game is promising, visually stunning and the devs keep us up to date on the progress being made on a weekly basis.

Buying this game right now however is more about supporting the development of the game then getting a game you can already properly play and enjoy early. So keep that in mind when deciding to purchase :)


You can also check their weekly updates about the game on youtube:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCa7W66RPP2X-BKPhhH1a4nw

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: Followed game since before release and through patches since release. Very disappointed; game is incomplete.

I purchased this game on the day of release; I followed it before it was even released on Early Access on Steam. Since then, I have kept my eye on the game as it rotted away in my Steam library. As a gamer who grew up on RTS, RPG, and Simulators, this game should be everything I desire in a game. It has so much potential; it breaks my heart in its current state. Yes, this game is beautiful. Yes, this game has endless character. But it is so very incomplete. It's early access, but that is no excuse. It has been almost two years now since release. We deserve more from this game. I would hate to see this game wind up alongside games like DayZ, known for sucking consumers in during Early Access and then providing a flop of a game. I cannot recommend this game, as much as I'd love to. If things improve, I will gladly and wholeheartedly change my review, but until then, it's a thumbs-down from me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[2016/1/1]

Let's get to the point. The game has a lot of promise and potential. I love the concept, the art and the design, but it has not reached that potential as of yet. The game has the city building (basics) pretty much down, but lacks most of the RPG/RTS features and deeper management aspects as of the moment. Beyond that, the game doesn't have very much to do once you get the buildings built and supply/production chains established, which is why the game is not at its peak.

I am still recommending it because I've noticed that the developers are very active, appreciative and humble, implementing user ideas/suggestions and being very open with their community. I also feel that the game has a lot of potential to be something great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fantastic. Despite it's mixed review rating, this game has many features and experiences to offer other Early Access games don't.

Pros:
- Very high quality style and details
- Randomly generated maps to increase play time
- A lot of interesting mechanics to the game including it's MOBA-like fighting style
- Easy to learn, hard to master, again, increasing play time
- Incredible AI
- Low hardware requirements

Cons:
- A lot of features that are not implemented are shown in HUDs and other windows

As you can see this list is definitely more on the positive side, but this is just what I think of it, why not buy and see how you like it? This game is definitely worth picking up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is really an amazing game. For people who like RPG, Action, Adventure, and building cities, this game is for you. Just note that it is in Early Access right now so there will be quite a few bugs and uneeded features. But aside from all of that, It is really fun to build a town, gather resources, upgrade structures, Battle against lots and lots of great enemies. Now, of course there is one huge downside to this game. As your progress, and as you build a huge and incredible Town, It starts to get boring. All of your structures end up being completely upgraded, everything is complete, and your end up with nothing to do. The worlds that players spawn in are only so big. they should be bigger though. Bigger worlds for building on, More enemies to take out, Stronger enemies to brawl with, More harder assults on your village from enemies. Everything becomes a bit too easy as your town becomes stronger and stronger.
So those are my thoughts on the game. There are many ups, and many downs. But the game is still in Early Access so I can't wait until it is finished. I hope everthing turns out amazing in the end!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just purchased the game last night, and as a result am sleep deprived today. The scope and ambition of this game is mighty impressive. Not coincidentally, it has been in development for years. The updates give me hope that development will progress at a decent pace.

It's very similar to the Settlers series, which is fine by me. Build up your villages with plenty of building and technology options, and meanwhile explore the map and slay enemies with your main hero and pals you find along the way.

The UI has some bits that could use some tweaking, to be certain. At least some shortcut keys exist but aren't indicated anywhere (e.g. 'I' shows inventory, with a hero selected 'C' brings up the character sheet, etc.)  Minor glitches are here and there, but thus far don't really detract too much from the game.

The biggest issue (at least with this latest build) is that the village population is extremely spiky: one minute, everybody's fat and happy, next minute you lose 80% of your people. As you hit different levels of culture" the needs of the village increase
date: and this causes the unhappiness. Again
recommended: not a show stopper - once you drop down in culture (because of the exodus) the needs decrease
hoursPlayed: happiness increases and you're back where you were. Rinse & repeat.\n\nIf you're a fan of the Settlers

Buy it if you're intrigued and ready to commit.  It's worth the cost."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What a great start. If this is the unfinished copy I can't wait to see the finished version and I'm happy to be part of the process. Has all of the best ideas from RTS and city builder games rolled into one. I love the way you can zoom in so close and look at the details of the little villagers working. No pixelated or tiny people like simcity games. Think more of the details in Warcraft 3.
Every single one of your villagers can level up and become a hero in his or her own right. Simple select one of your villagers, add epic loot taken from the local monster community and send them off to slay wolves trolls and necromancers in the hills.
Obviously it is still early days and many features are currently not operational. But the game is still loads of fun as it stands.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great overall building game with some cool ARPG elements like equipment management and unique heros. Graphics are nice for the look the game is going for and it runs smoothly. It's got a helpful tutorial that will walk you through setting up a small village and teach you all the controls. It's definately more of a building and town management game right as combat is sparse in sandbox mode. Only the combat I've seen is  the occational bear that wanders too close to my hunters and the rat men that were guarding the iron mine close to the starting point. I'm sure it picks as you progress, and the campaign has more fighting if that's what you want.

My biggest complaint is villager management. It's easy enough to assign villagers to a role through the building recruitment dialog, but there's no way that I've seen to select them from the overhead view without just clicking straight on them. It's hard to tell who's who unless you've learned to recognize the outfits at a glance and equiping individual villagers is an outright pain in the you know what. The only way to assign villagers to combat is to box select them, which is not ideal as you may be sending poorly equiped villagers to die while your axe-weilding woodsmen and bow-sporting hunters carry on like nothing's wrong. I'd prefer to see a window with all your guys in it similar to what a lot of RTSs have or at least the ability to set groups that can be selected with a single button click.

Again, though, it's in good shape for an Early Access game, and they update on a regular basis. If you like ARPGs and RTS games, I'd give it a shot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to try and give a quick review.

DISCLAIMER: I'll go ahead and point out that I only have about 10 hours played on this game, and this game is far from complete, but I believe Folk Tale has a chance at being something great.

Note that this game's developement has been very long and slow. It's unfortunate, but with small developers taking on big tasks that happens. I've definitely gotten impatient with this game's progress at times, but the one factor that gives me the utmost faith in this game, and its developers, is consistency. They push out a stable build about every month or so, and it bring content and mechanics every time. This game is shaping up, and it is starting to look very good.

Right now the story line isn't fleshed out very well, so you've got a little bit of a city builder going. But the thing I find most captivating is that it is some sort of RPG-RTS-City Builder-Simulator hybrid. All of your townsfolk can level up and equip armor and items, making every unit you have unique. Then you have hero units that you recruit as the game goes on. Each one has different abilities (like rogues, healers, warriors, etc). You can give them gear as well. It's just a really cool idea and is improving all the time. There are dungeons to explore, enemies that try to invade, and everything between.

The game is also visually appealing to me. It's not cutting edge by any means, but the art has that World of Warcraft kind of charm to me.

The price of this game is pretty steep considering how much content is missing. As it stands you can get about 15 or so hours out of the content before you're stuck trying to find things to do other than min-maxing your units and town. But I recommend it if you see it on sell or you're looking for a game like this to get behind.

If you're not looking to buy, I at least recommend following the development of this game. When it is done it's going to be very good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I saw this game I thought it would be an amazing fantasy type strategy/sandbox game, sadly, due to the bugs, lacking of content and poor execution of its key features to a degree this game was a disappointment which has heavily made me turn away from Early Access Gaming. Yes it is in alpha, but as other critics have clearly pointed out, it could have been much greater by now in all senses. My most annoying problem with the game wasn't the bugs, but instead the heavy lacking of interactivity due to the poor camera system and interactive features which were essentially non-existent through my play through. The video made it seem that the villagers would come to life and fill one with a sense of realism in the sense of the town which in turn makes everything more meaningful, but there is very little of that. You barely interact with people, no personal conversations or quests, just stats and names and the randomly generated chat sequences with other NPCs that pop up. My only nice point about this not yet finished game is the art. It is the only immersive thing about the experience of this early access title that is  worth any looking into, but yet, you don't have to buy the game for that! Just go on google images or dwell in the images above!

My rating is -2/5, 24%, 2/10 and I'd only recommend this game to the developers so they can look over this poor excuse for a game and entitle it a time waster. I'm sure as the development progresses it will be indeed better, but it’s not worth its current charge, simply get it when it’s finished.

(My own opinion and this information is related/valid through my personal play through with the game)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR : I would not recommend this game for its low replayability, and painfully slow development speed (what they are doing with the money from sales? definately not hiring developers).
Despite the developers campaign to improve its tattered reviews on Steam, they only seem to reply to reviews and havent actually addressed any of the issues, and are now only breaking up patches into smaller segments.

The combination of a medieval city-like building game with that of an RPG style is a great and unique spin on the conventional strategy game, introduced by developers who bring a fresh new perspective to the table. With a great genre combination, and an overall awesome concept- the only aspect that truly disapoints is the execution.

In its current state, replayability and game functionality are low. The game is quite easy (even on the hardest map) and only takes 2-3 hours to have seen it all. I understand it is in very early development, but the game as remained in an alpha state for years now. The response to it's players complaining of a slow pace was to seemingly split up its patches into smaller patches, all composing of bug fixes.
I would like to recommend buying this game to support the development team, but it may just be trying to fuel a fire that has no oxygen left.

If you buy this game, don't get me wrong you will have fun for a few hours, but thats it. You still have a ways to go before playing this game with all it's features and content. I'm obviously no game development expert, but I do not at all feel this game will be finished Early or even Mid 2016 (Make me eat my words please!).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been with early access from the very beginning, and this game has ALWAYS shown such great promise. Yes the game is still in development, but it’s to the point now where it’s fun and challenging. The hard maps are hard, frustrating, and extremely addicting to play. The updates are more-or-less pretty regular and new content is being added all the time.

I think what makes this so endearing to me is that the developers really listen to feedback from players and try hard to add suggestions that make sense and increase playability. So much has gone into this game that came in from community suggestions that it’s completely different from when it was orininally launched. When I initially downloaded it, sure it was fun… but after about 2 hours I had seen and done it all. But now that Sandbox is here and stable… I can’t get enough. Great Job guys.

On a side note; I kinda feel sorry for the new people coming into game at this point. They will have missed the early “Tutorial” game and all the humor it held. But I feel certain it will be back soon, as there are still silly little things tucked away here and there in the game which promise copious amounts of jocularity to come.

I highly suggest that if you join early access, you join the Dev Hang-outs and give feedback. You never know, your suggestion could turn a great game into something Legendary!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought Folk Tale a while ago and have not played much, about 6 hours. While the game still has a ways to go, I am confident that Games Foundry will produce a very good product. Why? Because they pump out regular updates, take the time to listen to their players, and use surveys to find out what their investors/players want! They are a very pro-active company and I enjoy the way they are approaching this project.

Their player-relations are also very good. Multiple times I have asked questions on the forums and have recieved rather swift responses! The game is on the right track, even though it did have a bit of an early turn around from a story-based RPG to a sandbox based RPG, where I can understand some players argument that they are not recieving the game they invested their money into. However, they may provide feedback to help Games Foundry produce the best game possible, because this company does listen. The best indicator of that is the fact that they made such a great turn around.

Another something that I like is that they have a roadmap on their site, detailing and outlining what they plan on making. It helps regular players like me understand what is to come and increases our faith in the company. So with that said, I will be giving Games Foundry and Folk Tale a big PLUS ONE. Can't wait for the next update and keep up the good work!

P.S. Defenitly more than one hour of playable content. No idea why people keep saying there is only one hour!

reviewerDisplayName: Drive Up in the Hollywood Hills
reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok definitely a good game. Actually it’s a phenomenal game! Some people complain about it being in alpha for a bit too long. Personally Idc, I'd rather they took t heir time to polish it than release it early and have it be incomplete. Before you read all the way through though, Ive only played the game for a few hours, and haven’t beaten any of the maps yet, so this review comes from limited experience and knowledge.

The Good:
-It’s fun and challenging, especially after you've progressed past your basic buildings (woodcutter, stonecutter and a food source)
-Challenging, but not too challenging. ♥♥♥♥ wanders into your town to cause a bit of havoc and stretch your resources. But you don’t have Beholders and Owlbears coming into town to ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up with lasers from their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s on a regular basis. They took most of my favorite things from Age of Empires, and combined it with my favorite things from Banished (also a good game, check it out) and then threw in a pinch of Skyrim/Oblivion and Stronghold 2. The result is amazing. You can't just turtle-up and mass an army of foot soldiers to steam roll from one end of the map to the other like you can in AoE. However it’s not as stupidly infuriatingly wonderfully hard as Banished is.
-It has the added bonus of being actually able to create soldiers (unlike Banished), and gives you enemies that you can go fight and loot. But by no means do you have to. If you like, you can just focus on the drinking of ale, the smoking of pipe weed, and finding a love of gardening.
-If you do decide to go out and ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up, it’s a challenge. The ♥♥♥♥ you fight keeps, proportionally, 1 step above you. So you have to actually engage in your combat. Most games allow you to step on spiders and kill mice and call it experience. Folk Tale does not.
-Individuality of the peasants. Now 9 out of 10 times this doesn’t actually matter. The 1/10 of the time it does is in the army. You can, after you've killed something, loot it for gear and treasure! So ♥♥♥♥ing neat, cause with that gear, you can equip Joe the manure shoveling leper, with the Mithril Great sword of ♥♥♥♥off and the Diamond Chest plate of Not In My House ♥♥♥♥♥, and then make Joe the savior of the land, riding valiantly on the monstrous size of his own ♥♥♥♥ which he presumably discovered after finding out he was such a badass and could slay demons with his own ♥♥♥♥ and a can-do attitude. Each peasant can be leveled up uniquely and it’s ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. You can either take the equipment or divide it out between your forces, making a well-rounded security force that is to be reckoned with. Or pour all of your resources into one hulking behemoth that could fight and beat Zeus, god of gods.
-Visually pleasing to look at
-Audio is likewise pleasing (kind of reminiscent of LOTR [which is the best series of movies ever made by mankind])
-There's a great variety of building to be placed and they all do different things.
-Enemies get more difficult to beat the further you venture from your starting point. ♥♥♥♥ gets crazy yo'.

The Bad:
Actually I don’t like 'bad' cause really this game is a gem in the making. So we’re going to say the Mediocre.

The Mediocre:
-The Elasticity leaves something to be desired
This is one big category cause every problem I have comes back to this blanket criticism. What I mean is that       the game doesn’t flow as smoothly as it could have.
1.	Buildings= There's a variety of buildings, which is good yes, but I feel some of them could be condensed. For instance I had run out of clothes and my villagers began to complain as their nips were starting to fall off from frostbite. Tight. Places Cotton field. Good. Places Tailor. Good, clothes will start to be produced. Wrong. Turns out you also had to place a “Weavers Emporium”. So my warehouse had stockpiled like 50 stocks of weaved cotton, that I then had to go into overtime to catch up on both rewarding and lashing the weavers to get them to work as fast as possible. It just seems to me, that since the only thing you use cotton for is clothes, it seemed kinda silly that you needed 3 ♥♥♥♥ing building to make one product. Placing, monitoring and upkeeping and extra building took away from the flow of the game.
2.	Your army/security force (4 people isn’t really an army). I have no problem with the small size, in fact I prefer it, it emphasizes tactics over brute strength. I have a slight issue with the equipping of your soldiers. If there was an ‘equip all’ button, that’d be fantastic. Having to click on the guardsmen, open their inventory, open your inventory. Click boots, move boots, click mail, move mail, click gloves, move gloves, click coif, move coif, then do that 3 to 7 more times is more than a lot tedious and it takes away from the game. Like ♥♥♥♥ I got wolves eating Jim the peasant and ♥♥♥♥ing the stonecutters just caught fire I gotta take care of this but noooo first I gotta do this painfully slow process.
3.	Researching Tech is a pain. It has a AoE feel of spending resource to research new tech, which is legit. Don’t fix what’s not broke right? Well you can go ahead and buy as many upgrades as you can afford at once, the problem is that once one is done, it won’t bounce to the second one. Say you research Chisels, hammers and masonry. Once Chisels is done, it’ll stop there, till you re-click the building, go to the tech tab and select the next tech to research. It leads to a lot of needles bouncing form building to building to check and recheck what tech is at what progress in what building then bouncing back to select the next tech to research even though you’ve already purchased it. Long story, anyway. It would be nice if, once you’ve bought a tech, it got automatically researched in the order they were purchased.
4.	Assigning peasants a job. This one has two in one. So 1.1 you build a building, tight. Assign 3 peasants to chop wood so you can leave your last one to keep foraging berries. Then later, when you have more peasants you go back to the building, assign a 4th peasant. Jim the farmer dies from a goblin attack, go to building and take 1 woodcutter and unassign him. Go to farm, assign new farmer. Now this doesn’t sound TOO annoying and honestly it’s not. This is my smallest beef with Folk tale. It’s nearly remedied by the ability to check a box on each building titles “auto-assign” which automatically makes sure the building is full of workers if able. You do however, have to go to each building and check the box off. Otherwise no luck. It’s be nice if the box was automatically set to autoassign or you could go to the options menu and make it so. Another (preferred) solution would be to do what “Banished” and have an entire menu that shows all the jobs, how many workers could be there, and how many workers are there currently. It accommodates the fast pace of “Banished” where the east section of your village can just die from a surprise earthquake. I think it would do well here In Folk tale to.
1.2 This, logically, should be my smallest beef, but it’s not. I like knowing where my peasants are. Like, in Aoe, you have a button to select all inactive peasants, in Stronghold they gather around the fire. In Folk Tale, I’ve got no ♥♥♥♥in’ clue where they are. And that bothers me immensely, as Im more than slightly anal-retentive and I like to specifically assign individuals to certain jobs. When I have to find four free peasants to turn into herbalists by scouring every nook and cranny of my town, its slightly annoying.

Anyway. That’s all. Sorry for the long post but I do really love this game already and wanted to offer every thought I had on the matter. As of now, I give it a solid 8.5/10. With some improvements to the flow and elasticity of the game I’d easily and happily give it a 10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game will appeal to those who enjoyed:

- Settlers 6: for economy (establishing production chains, using workers, etc);
- Warcraft 3: for combat and occasional dungeoneering missions, visuals and day-night cycle.

However, please note that the game is still in development, so certain features might be missing (like world map, for example). Content-wise it's playable. Campaign and sandbox are playable, but by no means are complete.

Personally, though, I would greatly appreciate to see the seasons change.

Basically, this game is what Settlers 7 should have been.

Definitely recommended.

- Buildings/res is not balanced or working as it should? (buildings when building it is not right as of yet or timing and res amount is way off for now going to be balanced later on)
- Battles is not fully there yet (no Heros or many other things that is going into the game)

- Leveling up dosen't work at the moment
- Stats/ablities isnt ready yet (Coming next update?)
- Only Tier 1 is in fuction (tier 2 and 3 is somewhat ready but not as of yet)
- Pathfinding not allways that cind with you..



Now its more about doing the awsome tutorial a thousend times :P

Havent seen how they are going to make us care about the peasnt and towns folk yet..
Atleast the devs are advancing this game and looks like they want to complete it with love in their hearts :) Leveling up works but skills after leveling up do not work (like more health to unit or damage and such).

No workable combat spells or attack abilitys (exept few prev build stuff just added in for fun).

So there is a long road to actuly get to say if I like the game or not but this far I have loved the game in how they update and were they go with this.

Editor is basic and creating maps by placeing tileset here and there not as advanced like hammer or have the same freedom (scripts

Based on what I have seen and read from others, I went and bought this game last night. I like it a lot and am really excited about updates in the future, not to mention the finished product!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updated Review:

I bought into the early access for Folk Tale a year ago and I have never regretted my purchase.   Prior to buying in, I haunted their Steam forum for a few weeks prior, mainly due to the negative reviews on their store page, and the entire time I was impressed by how interactive and helpful the GF devs were on a daily basis.  There was a lot of animosity being leveled at them at the time because they did something virtually unheard of in game development and that was change direction based on the feedback they received from their fanbase prior to being Greenlit.  Whether or not one agrees with their decision, it's an admirable move because so much more often gamers are not listened to and their opinions fall on deaf ears.

So here we are, a year later and even though Folk Tale is just a couple patches away from 0.3.0 (that's my estimate and I could be wrong), and that's the version the devs themselves caution those who want a playable experience to wait for, I am even more reassured than I was a year ago because I've seen first hand how accomadating and unfailingly interactive the GF devs are on a daily basis and I've been watching the weekly dev hangouts each Sunday since they first started and each week, I'm amazed at what they accomplish from one week to the next.

Without a doubt, the GF devs are passionate about their game and it shows.  If you have even the slightest misgivings about this early access or just early access in general,  take a peek at the Sunday dev hangouts on twitch and keep tabs on it.  These guys go out of their way to make sure we know exactly what's going on in development.

How many other early access developers do the same?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like RTS games, I can recommend Folk Tale. It's a bit of both Warcraft 3 and Settlers. Warcraft 3 because it contains an RPG element and you build structures to gain resources but Settlers, because there's a little bit micro-management with your buildings and villagers.

I watch the GamesFoundry stream on twitch every Wednesday and through that, I know they are constantly updating the game to become better. They also listen to the community and make changes if necessary.
Which was evident from the start when the game wouldn't let you train female villagers into certain working roles, but people complained so they fixed it.

As of this date: Aug/2015, there is no victory point. Meaning  you will play a map and it will simply never end unless you did badly. However, that'll most likely change soon.

If you like to craft your own maps and give them out to a community to play, the game got a powerful and simple editor for you to mess around with. Steam workshop will be available for the game soon to facilitate map making and sharing.

Finally, I would like to list some of my pros and cons:

Pros
-Fun game play.
-Great British humor (Think modern Monty Python).
-Excellent map editor.
-Developers heed feedback.
-Beautiful music score.
-Heroes and villagers can level up.
-Love the loot system and that you can give new gear to your heroes and various professions.
-You can research upgrades for your buildings.

Cons:
-No end goal to a map yet.
-Voice acting is a bit wonky and can be repetitive and annoying.
-Sound design and foley is less than adequate.
-No guard tower unless you build a wall which can ruin your village layout.
-No story in the game, however, I know it is coming.
-Professions, like the baker, will get flour and return it to the bakery and it'll automatically generate the bread. You will never see him make the bread which makes me feel like he should just be a carrier instead of a fully dressed baker.
-While crafting is nice, it is a micro-management that becomes tedious for a large village, as you have to hunt down the house that can craft the item. It would be much better with a crafting tab that contained all the recipes.
-You cannot set what sort of crop you want to grow until the field is complete. While minor, if you are pulled away from your field before or as it's being built, you might forget to set it to grow cotton and later on wonder why you never get any cloth bolts made.

Early Access Review

Whilst not entirely finished (as was expected with an early access game) I thoroughly enjoyed playing through what I have played so far.  The game has a uniquely quirky vibe to it and isn't afraid to poke a little fun at itself which I find refreshing.  I absolutely adore the art of this game, it reminds me of games like Fable, warcraft or torchlight but has a personality of its own as well. - Dec 2014

UPDATED REVIEW BELOW - May 2015:

Does this game have longevity potential to provide more than 8-12 hours of village builder gameplay?

Currently I have over 28 hours played, 24 of those hours have been recent experience. I bought the game when it first hit early access and played the tutorial several times through. This game has come a long long way since then. It still has a ways to go, but the sandbox game has a lot of potential. The management of all the different buildings, villagers, resources, upgrades and trying to keep the villagers warm, fed, happy and healthy all serve to keep you on your toes while you expand your village and explore the surrounding landscape. This is a game that I don't tend to burn myself out on, It's a game that I keep coming back to whenever the GF guys add something new.

With only 28 hours played you can't really call me a fan boy, that being said, I do enjoy this game and I expect to get another 100 hours or more out of it in the next year or more. It has great potential, it has great art design, great mechanics and a great feel to it. If there was a downside, I would say at the moment it is content. With only three or four maps currently available if you tend to burn through content you might run out quick.


With all that being said, with 24 hours played on the new content I can honestly say that I still have a lot more time to give to this great title and I really look forward to seeing more from Games Foundry.

http://www.gamesfoundry.com/gameguide/gettingstarted/

Check out the gameguide if you are interested in the features currently available.

it has been a while since I took a look at this game.
Last time it was a year after it's first early launch to see how far it had progressed, and sadly it was not up to my hopes.

Now here we are again, spurred on by a comment from the dev himself asking me to take another look.

Now here is what I expected to happen after a long time of developement, it now feels much closer to a game I could play for days on end. It reminds me now much of the old cultures series mixed with the recent banished.

Is it a completed game now? oh no. It is still much in a state of developement, so plz do not judge it as a finished product or buy it because you want a culture esque game, wait till it is released, or buy it to show support knowing full well it is a work in progress.

This is not the game i played so many moths ago, but a much better one showing me that not every early acces game out there is only after your money.

Glad I took another look on this one, and hope for a truly superb game at launch that will take away many hours from my life, for now I will se how far I get before a bear kills everyone of my hunters in game before I set out to scour them from my lands

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review will attempt to insight you, dear reader, about what isn't already obvious to you.


Folk Tale is a fantasy city builder with dungeoneering RPG elements. There's loot and you get to assign it! Also it has a fantastic art style. At the bottom of this review you can find info on the games that inspired Folk Tale.

The game is dedicated to being a sandbox & having a fleshed-out campaign. All of these facts give it very big boots to fill.

The Good Lots of genuine potential.
Everybody here gains exp & levels up! Woo!
It's tackling a niche, if you're reading this chances are you feel drawn to something refreshing yet familiar
Atmosphere is well crafted - both auditory and visually the game is beautiful.
Build your town and raise your heroes & soldiers to glory, equipping them for scaling threats.
Veterans of gaming, the developers have a clear vision but listen to the community
Tools used to make the game are given to players, you get the same resources as the devs
The modding community here could explode - parallels between WC3 and FT start to show :)
Crafting
Randomly generated items = this is not yet implemented!

The Bad The game is Early Access, and it aims to be delivered by the end of 2016. And although I personally feel confident in the project, we all know of hiccups that can happen.
There are a lot more features destined to be released soon, but it can be disappointing not knowing exactly what the full game will contain. The goods are a plus, the lack of clarity a minus.
There's a lot of things on the plate right now, which means features get released but not everything already out is polished, you can really get frustrated at that - for example the UI needs some  updates.
At the moment (and I will strive to keep the review up-to-date) there's not many hours of content to enjoy.
Because the game has changed direction the updates seem patchy and can really be frustrating at times

The Verdict
Overall is it worth INVESTING in? Absolutely!

As a game however - right now - you have to be willing to have patience. It's not complete and although fun, is brief.


Hope that helps!

-----------------------------------------Similarities-----------------------------------------

The following titles I will try to arrange in order of how much inspiration they've served to Games Foundry:

WarCraft III
Banished
More action orientated games (like DotA)

But it's a bit more than that. Like any city building game you build things like farms and butchers and make little production chains to keep your people happy, and watch them in their day to day lives. thats the City building and town sides of it. But what really makes it shine is the way you start to really get attached to your people. Each charecter can be equipped and taken on missions so you start to feel as though you have helped each one grow, and will probably get favourites and the ones you don't like so much and this brings your little town to life.
There is also a pretty cool editor which lets you make your own map and therefore your own folk tale story.
This is an EDITED review, my last one complained about the Devs never releasing updates nor keeping us informed for a long stretch of time but I have to say this has been sorted to I am now recommending this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updated review:

Updating now to change to thumbs up review, due to progress in development and attentiveness of game staff!

The game ahs some ways to go with a few things being implemented, but for what it has right now it's a functioning playable game. You now have the option to save (one slot, though it won't tell you it's saved, it just does it) and you can continue later. The graphics in the game look beautiful for its style, and the villagers seem to understand (for the most part) what they are meant to do for their tasks. My only issue I'm having is constant complaints of sickness when I have everything everyone says you need to keep villagers healthy.

The game is on its way, progressively with good updates. Worth a play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This could be, and likely will be, a fun game.  As it stands, it is not.  The campaign is half baked and poorly implemented, with multiple, long stretches of running back and forth across the same terrain just killing time.  It plays like early ♥♥♥♥♥♥ther quests where you run around, kill things, come back, run back, kill some more, return, rinse, repeat, rinse repeat.

The sandbox mode is interesting, but also broken and woefully incomplete.  Each resource can be gathered/created in exactly one way, and if that way is not present, too bad.  No animals around to hunt so you can gather hides?  You lose. Want to buy it at the market?  It takes 50 of those non-present resources to build a market. The economy cannot recover from the absence of a single critical component and your time has now been wasted.

I expected the game to be rough and in need of polish.  It is not ready for polishing--it needs some core development, some tuning and THEN some polishing.  This game could be good in about a year.
