reviewText:
Early Access Review

Folk Tale, the Fantasy/SRPG.

Now Ive had this game since literally the first day its been on Steam. The game is by GamesFoundry, a great group of guys who are trying to make this unique game come to life more and more with every update. Although my hours logged arnt that much compared to the others here I have played all through the maps and am currently playing with the map editor, so this gives me a refined base for the game.

Lets start shall we?

Graphics:
The graphics are like that of the Overlord game series, but with less doom and gloom. The etxtures are simply wonderful, even close up you can notice small details in the armor of your population, the riffits on the buildings, the notches in the shields and so much more.

While the graphics arnt on a serious manner, it gives the game a serious cartoonish feel to it without being on the Borderlands cartoonish side.

I would  give the graphics an 8/10.

Audio:
The games audio is beautiful as it has multiple sound tracks and a bit more short bits of music for special events. This makes the game feel alot more adventurous and a bit more mysterious.

Aside from the music of the game there is also the ambiance to the game. You can hear the frogs croak in the swamps, the wind howling in the tundras, and the trees swooshing in the grasslands. If you zoom to street level in your town you can hear people talking, music playing in the tavern, bees buzzing in the bee hives ect. It really brings the game to life and I hope they expand on this.

I would give audio a 9/10

Gameplay:
In the gameplay aspect of this game it gets a bit odd but fun. The basics of the game are like any other, build your base/village, keep your people fed and happy, defend yourself, profit. While its very copy and paste in other games its very unique in this one. During the missions in the game while you build your village up there are creatures which come for your villagers heads during any point in the game. It may be goblins, toadkin, or spiders (The spiders are 1337). If you manager to survive the onslaught to get enough city guards and crossbowmen then youre set pretty much, as long as you use them wisely.

A unique thing the guys at GamesFoundry are working on is a Faction system, much like in World of Warcraft, or ArchAge once you build enough reputation with 1/2 factions on the map they reward you. You may pick a hero from each faction that youre high up in while the other faction tends to hate you more and more, like your ex. But unlike your ex you can actually kill the faction that doesnt like you, or the one you dont like.

Another cool feature is the items in the game are used on the models in game. An example is the city guard, just a man with a helmet, padded dress armor, and a pike. You can give the guard a bigger pike and the model changes, an axe and it changes, ect. Same with armor, although not all models work for changing pretty much all of them do. Of course there are restrictions such as guards cant use bows and crossbowmen cant use flaming swords, its still a unique feature that focuses on detail and I love it.

GamesFoundry also said they are working on a massive amount of content for the game as well, hopefully sometime in the coming months the content will be finished for the many items they are adding and I can make another eview on more aspects of the game.

I would give gameplay a 9/10


If you guys enjoyed this review I would check the game out! Watch the videos here or on YouTube, read the forums, or if I compelled you enough get the game?  The game is updated very frequently as well, so thats always a plus to have the creators improving their work often.

Comments, questions, concerns? There are forums on 'Should you buy Folk Tale?' as well as the 'FAQ' forum for anything you could ask. Hope to see you in the community :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game-changer and I - totally recommend - Folk Tale

Probably the game i've been searching for since I gave up with all the new samey-samey stuff.
I even reinstalled Warcraft III and Age of Mythology for some decent RTS play.

Back to this game...
I'd say it's a mash up of WC3, Clash of Clans, maybe even Fable-like graphics and just a  huge new nugget of gaming goodness. Yeah it may not be complete, but it's running pretty well and there is just so, so, so, so much potential here. I absolutely love this so far. I haven't come across any faults so far in my 3 hours of play, apart from one crash but I completely understand, it's in progress and little blips are a given.
Really excited to have come across this game and that i'll be able to watch all the new additions as it becomes one of the best games I have played. Quirky, cute and just lovely.

Honestly, great job to the small group who are behind this growing masterpiece. Like most people i'd have a couple of suggestions for additions, but you guys are doing a great job already.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm usually terribly derisive of the many unfinished games being sold on Steam. In the case of Folk Tale, however, I'm incredibly glad I picked it up. It won't be finished any time soon, so if you're looking for something you can jump in on for cheap, and have a mostly playable game, you'd best look somewhere else. On the other hand, if you want to watch a game as it's being made, if you want a developer who actively engages with the community as it works, and if you want clear goals from an early-access that are visibly being met? This is the game for you.
I never thought I'd enjoy what amounts to newsletters as much I have, but I actually find myself looking forward to the monthly patch notes and dev blogs. This is what all early access games should be. This isn't another Day Rust Z deal, nor is it an early access game that will never get finished or - worse- finish without making good on its promises. If you're reading this in a year or more, when the game is nearly complete or even completed, I promise you it's worth your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been burned by early access games before (looking at you, Doublefine) but I still don't regret buying Folk Tale.  Yes, it's been in EA for a very long time, but the devs are active and communicative and there are regular updates.  What's already there is still impressive and has a great cartoony-fantasy feel to it.  Progress is steady and it's fun to watch how the game evolves.  If you're on the fence, put it on your watch list, don't be scared by the negative reviews, and keep an eye on the updates until you're ready to try it.  I think this is going to be one of my favourite games once it's completed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game in EA. Am I glad I bought it?

Wooooorddddddd. This is the reason EA exists. I'm having a bit of fun with the game. Am exceptionally eager for each step of the road map. Dev team is responsive and absurdly engaged - how is it big budget games are less responsive than a small team?

You get to impact the evolution of a game, and it seems to be on excellent track to a final state.

The game - Current State

Build a Age of Empires complex town, get some sweet visuals, throw your population at problems and secrets, have a teasing sip of the coming standout gem - the hero system. Lack of some functions currently implemented in dev client thingamajig can be frustrating - not being able to look around while paused - but, ya know, it's called EA for a reason.

10/10 - more excited for this than Heavensword, Tacos, or my sunburn to go away

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Folk Tale is a unique RPG, City Builder hybrid.  I like the art style and game controls are easy to get the hang of and just feel comfortable.  It is very easy to sit down for a short play session only to realize hours have gone by.  I love the fact that I am not stuck in a linear progression like story mode.  Another nice rpg like feature of folk tale is that you can level peasants by using them to fight npc mobs threatening your village.  Individual peasants may also equip armor drops or armor you have crafted.
Would buy again and recommend, great game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start out by stating this is an EARLY ACCESS game. It is not a completed game and many of the reviews on here judge it as if it is completed.

The game shows so much promise, and from what the devs have discussed/mapped out for its future...it will only get better. The systems in this game (even those not fully implemented yet) all meld together so well and make every second enjoyable. Whether you are building your very first building or attacking some group of enemies...it just captures your attention.

To those of you that are complaining development is taking too long? Bah, take as long as you please Devs, this concept deserves as much polish as possible. I cannot wait to play this current build some more, the next build, and the finished game whenever that may come.

This is the game I have been craving, a smooth mix between Fantasy RPG, city building, and RTS. If you like any (or all) of those 3 genres, check this game out.

Just remember, every dollar you spend on getting this game now just quickens the process or allows more things to be added.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has been on early access for two years, when i bought it a few weeks after early access launch it was already a fairly interesting game, the problem was that it was story driven, and content was only for a few hours play back then. In dialogue with the community they shifted the game more toward a sandbox game than completely story driven. The game still features many intrinsic story elements, which at release can be used to introduce the same story driven maps that were in the original tutorial map back in the day.

I honestly like the way this game is going, and are looking forward to future updates. Updates come relatively often, and I feel there have been significant and helpful changes. I like where this game is going, but it may not be for everyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bernard, who had been recently recruited into the town militia, grabbed a shiny new helm and leather boots, before embarking on an adventure to reclaim some kind of artifact from a monastery filled with monk werewolves.  With one swing of his mighty halberd, Bernard barely scratched the first werewolf he encountered and was killed.  While short lived, Bernard rose from the ranks of nothingness to being a great knight and protector of his people.  Truthfully, he wasn’t so great, but nonetheless, he climbed from being a simple peasant to someone with tremendous potential, even though he never realized it.

Much like Bernard, Folk Tale is a game with tremendous potential as it moves forward.  Before I continue, I want to remind everyone that this is an early access game.  Numerous features and concepts have not been implemented, bugs can pop-up anywhere, and the game is far from being completed.  It can be frustrating to see an icon that has no function or to open a building detail page only to notice several upgrades are listed, but none function.  If you are not prepared or have no desire and patience for an incomplete game, do not get this game.  Unless you would like to help fund the project, then by all means, purchase this game.

With that being said, Folk Tale is still an enjoyable experience if a fantasy city builder, with role-playing and questing elements is something that peaks your interest.  As of the current build, gameplay options include a campaign style tutorial, sandbox mode, and game editing.  The tutorial introduces the basics of building, economy and combat.  It is here that the RPG and questing elements are located.  The sandbox mode is what one would expect in that it provides total freedom to build your town without constraints or objectives.  This is the perfect testing ground to further learn the game and explore some of the currently available features Folk Tale has to offer.  And if neither the campaign inspired tutorial nor sandbox mode interests you, fire up the game editor and create your own content.

While diverse gameplay modes and editors are great, it’s the core content that drives games into being worthwhile endeavors and consumers of our precious time.  Here is where Folk Tale has set itself up to shine.  From the moment you begin playing the game, the charming, fairy-tale inspired art direction and vibrant color palette catch and hold your attention.  The landscape and buildings come alive through color, detail and lighting (there is even day and night cycles).  The level of detail, whether it be a flower covered rolling hill, a waterfall fed stream with a pedestrian bridge, a newly constructed building or even a simple peasant, is visual treat.  While exploring the land, small, satisfying details are reviled, such enterable buildings that are alive with people and props, which make you want to continue on and see what else is down the road.  The sound is also on par with the great visuals.  The town is alive with the sounds of foot-steps, birds chirping, flowing water, wind and much more.  Once zoomed in close, brief conversations and dialogue from different peasants can be over-heard, much of it quite humorous.  The soundtrack playing in the background also does an excellent job of drawing you into the Folk Tale world with its whimsical melodies.

Nice visuals and sounds alone are not enough to push a game into the realm of worthiness.  For that, there must be great gameplay mechanics and features.  With the present build, Folk Tale is just barely achieving that level.  Presently, a variety of buildings can be constructed and the basic economy system is up and running.  For example, you can build a mill and farms to harvest wheat, which in turn is taken to the stock pile to be stored and later collected by the baker so toast can be produced.  This system of intermingling buildings to produce a usable product is well received.  It’s no so overly complicated that excessive micro-managing of every aspect of life is required, but there is enough to keep you busy and engaged.  However, many other buildings and features, such as upgrades and research, have not been implemented in the current build, but the blueprint is there.  This can be frustrating at times, but as I said before, the game is still being developed and being able to see what is down the road is promising.

One of the most promising and intriguing features are the RPG elements.  Going back to Bernard, I was pleasantly surprised when I selected him and noticed he was a named character.  In looking around the town, I noticed everyone, from the baker to the woodcutter to the barmaid, had a name.  While some where recycled, they each had a name nonetheless.  Beyond that, the foundation for character leveling, special abilities and inventory management was present too.  The farmers leveled up the more the fields were worked, the militia men leveled up after defeating enemies, and so it was for the rest of the working town folks.  Individual character Inventories could be accessed, which allowed for items, such as better armor or weapons, to be provided.  This in turn raised stats such as strength and armor, among other things.  And each different character, depending on their present occupation, had special abilities that could be activated.  For example, the town priest could heal units or pacify enemy units after activating some of his abilities.  Frustrating, many of these features are present, but not implemented into the current game build.  But knowing these will someday be implemented provides tremendous promise and intrigue.

All in all, Folk Tale is a visually appealing game with massive potential.  It could become one of those rare games which successfully fuses different aspects of some of the most beloved game types into one cohesive unit all while still being unique.  However, time will tell as development is 45% complete at the present time.  Concerning whether or not you should buy this game, I’d say it depends to your level of patience with early access games and your interest level in city building, light PRG, and strategy gaming.  If you can deal with this game being a work-in-progress and have an interest in this style of game, then I’d say it’s a definite purchase.  For being incomplete and sometimes frustrating do to non-implemented features in the current build, I can honestly say I have enjoyed my time and can’t what to explore the finished world of Folk Tale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game when it was in very early access, whilst the developers seem very keen and offer many updates on their progress, very little ever seems to get done. Have they run out of money? A key programmer has left for pastures new? I don't know, but what I do know is nothing much has happened in the year or so since I bought this. I have a horrible feeling my money has been wasted and I should have backed someone else.

The game itself (what there is of it) is fun for about an hour but once you finish the tutorial there is little else to do, it looks like the recent update has made an attempt at a level designer but this itself looks amateurish and lacks any structure. Maybe one day this game will be finished, if there is then a demo I suggest you download that first before forking out for the 'finished' product.

I really cannot recommend this game in it's current state, hopefully when/if the game is finished then I can update this mini review and wholeheartedly back this game, but judging on this past years performance I fear not. But time will tell, in the meantime I recommend Banished as it of a similar ilk but perhaps not as ambitious as this product and is of a far simpler nature.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Jan 1/14 - The game concept looks like it has a lot of potential, but it's not worth buying into for early access. I've had it sitting in my library for months and months and all that's availible is the tutorial. Wait until it's more developed before revisiting it.

Mar 23/14 - Decided to pop in to see what's new. Game now boots to a title screen with a few new options to edit landscapes and characters, but under the Play option, all that's availible still is the tutorial. Might be fun to play with the landscape editor if you're into game design, but for players it still hasn't advanced beyond the tutorial.

May 5/14 - Still only tutorial availible in the play mode.

May 28t/14 - New update published for the game. There is now a customizer for users to fiddle with the intricate details on character models (not sure how noticable customized nose length will be in such an overhead style of play). There is also a Sandbox mode added. This sandbox mode is not fully developed and is still in infancy stages. Users can construct buildings (they will not use up resources to do so) but will be unable to use them. More just a quick simulator of how you might layout a town when/if it becomes fully developed. Many buttons have not been activated yet, including map controls.

June 5/15 - This game has taken a long time to move into a playable state. However, I did some playing last night, and while some functions are not yet activated, the game is very much usable. I would now recommend this.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhere to begin. FolkTale has become improved greatly. I haven't played it for too long so I still don't have the best experience but I will say that this game has improved massively since launch. You can now build your own world (Which I have no clue how to do but the option is there) and your own character which isnt exactly at the level of Skyrims but then again this game doesnt have the funding of Skyrim. The story isnt exactly a masterpiece but it is passible. This game has a large choice of things to do and by large I mean MASSIVE. Since my first review the game has earned the title of Village Builder RPG and it is a more enjoyable game to play. Even if you aren't going to buy as of this point of time I would keep an eye on the developer and Folk Tale as I have seen massive improvments to the game unmatched by most others. This game doesnt get anywhere near the amount of attention it deserves. Though it isn't perfect it sure isn't a bad game I am can promise you it will continue to improve judging by the features already added. One last thing you need a BUFF PC to be able to play this at 60fps despite its cartoonish look. Overall I rate Folk Tale 8/10 for its ever improving gameplay.

Early Access Review

My first impressions of the game 2 years ago were nothing but negative. The controls were wonky, the game was prone to crashing, and there wasn't much gameplay to speak of. At the time, I believe the price for the game was about $20, so I wrote up a brief negative review as to pay proper respects to my wasted money.

Now, however, the game is far closer to what I initially expected when I first purchased the game. It's fairly entertaining, has charming voice acting (No more toast jokes either as far as I can see), and I'm genuinely interested to see what else the developers have in store. I recommend this game to anyone looking for a more personalized, RPG-like strategy game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's beautiful. It's a city-builder RPG that plays like an RTS. It's Folk Tale.

For a company with only 9 developers, only one of them being a programmer, this is amazing. It takes a long time for this game to develop, but it is already looking nicely. Artstyle is glorious, and the idea is great. They are focusing on gameplay now, and they are adding several gameplay enhancements and mechanics.

The game still has a long way to from the time of writing this, january 2015, but I believe that they will get there and this will become an awesome game.

Be sure to be watching the developer streams on wednesday (previously on sunday), to pick up the latest development progress and ask questions to the developers.

Edit: To anyone wondering if you can save in sandbox, the answer is YES, via console. Look for the console guide on their website. It might say that it doesn't fully work, but it does work. In fact, right now, it's almost bug-free.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT (15/06/2015): Well, this turned quite well. After some long months away from Folk Tale I can only say I was pleasantly surprised with how much the game has changed for the better.

Everything I said in my old review of the game (posted below) was improved. Now there's a pretty solid sandbox mode with a lot of different buildings available, a working save/load game, and overall a great game that will consume some hours of fun playing.

Although still in development, now it really gives me something to look for in the future. Made me a believer again. Here's hoping to a continually good development.


(OLD REVIEW) The game itself has a great potential. The only problem is the rate of development. It's really, REALLY slow. Like I-bought-this-game-a-year-ago-and-too-little-was-added slow. So far it's only available a tutorial (that shows a lot of the upcoming final game, with some great gameplay mechanics), a really incomplete sandbox mode, with a lot of things not yet implemented (you can't even save/load) and nothing more.
Sure, it's early access, but compared to other dev teams that usually send out various updates with a lot of content, it's quite bad. I only ask for a functional sandbox mode. Buy at your own risk.

TL;DR: Awesome ideas/gameplay; still very incomplete; slow game development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I been wanting to try this game for a while but never thought about buying it until yesterday, since it went on sale and I was all hooray its on sale I can finally test it out.

1. Tutorial map is easy and you get the hang of the game if you start on that map first, not like me who was all ooh okay load this easy one and try to figure out how to play.

2. Village pictures are all bald men even for the women when clicked on Oo

3. Rotation is pretty slow and clunky it takes foreeeeeeever just to turn the map around in order to see a different angle.

4. Micromanagement is not fun. I do not want to keep lashing or rewarding my workers to keep productivity up, though I do like the research idea that increases productivity. Get rid of the Lash and Reward, keep the research.

5. No matter how many taverns I put out to give villagers fun, there never seems to be enough fun and they all end up leaving the village cos it sucks. I even had all the research done on the taverns and that did nothing to help the situation at all.

6. Sometimes it crashes.

7. The storage house has research but sadly you can't do any of it, the same goes for the barracks you can't do any of the research on that either.

Edit:

After the responses from the Developers some time ago I have continued to play Folk Tale, and in addition I have also put out videos on youtube of me going over some of the points and gameplay. I can only say this game continues to improve despite slow progress, so far I've been doing the experimental builds and honestly like how things are going so far.

Games Foundry also watch my videos for any points that I make, and have often left me tips and hings in the comment section to help me on my way. Which I can only say this is pretty top notch of them, so in this regard I will continue to play and video Folk Tale with each new update and review the changes.

I have changed my recommendation from No to Yes.

Issue #1 ... I have to buy shirts from market because I can't build the necessary buildings. Took me a 2 games to figure this out because everyone eventually left the village which is frustrating.

Issue #2 ... The campaign got stuck when I went to talk to Nara. It created a permanant Willow character stuck at the throne room and an additional one that became playable.  I could get the antidote for the quest but when I returned nothing happened and the stuck Willow was still there with talk to Nara and return to Nara" both remained unable to be checked off.

Issue #4 ... If a non hero character dies any inventory dies with them.

Issue #5 ... Many of the buildings and upgrades are not supported yet which makes balancing economy and defence semi difficult.

Issue #6 ... If you craft weapons at the blacksmith for a proffession (in my case woodcutter) you are unable to unstack them. - I created 8 axes for 2 different camps (4 woodcutters each) and was forced to drop all 8 in the camp inventory. Additionally once an item is placed in a building inventory - it is unable to be removed while in use even if only 1 item on a multiple item stack is being used.

Issue #7 ... The carrots harvest value is too low.  I had 6 fields of carrots with 50 population and couldn't keep carrots in inventory.

Issue #8 ... Berries stop being able to be harvested as soon as you build any other type of food harvest building.

Issue #9 ... I wiped out the camp of Tauren type creatures but they would randomly spawn an attack - either have them respawn in the camp so you can guage when an attack will come or eiliminate them once they are gone.

Issue #10 ... Better defined use of gems
recommended:
charms etc... I can equip them but there is no indication of what they do. Same for many lootable items... spider webs etc .

Issue #11 ... I chose to leave the goblin in the cage in Kenny's hideout but then it was permanantly there... possibly an option to come back and release him later.

All in all a good game and I understand it's still somewhat in development. Hope this helps!

"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's actually pretty awesome. Unlike some games that are alike this function to some degree as a realistic village. You can't just spam units because you can only support the population of your town which makes it far more realistic than some other RTS games. The game is just really limited. The campaign is alot of running between two places to talk to someone, but the gameplay overall provides enough to keep you busy. In addition, the sandbox mode needs some work. It includes the same people as the campaign but no one is good or bad, you have to kill everything on the map for some reason, no one is your ally. And sandbox is very limiting because after you annihilate your opposition with your one soldier, there's nothing else to do. No one attacks or anything. But overall, I love the economy system of managing a village and is why I recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like the idea of this game. Of course it still has some way to go. My comments as of patch 0.3.3:
- The issue with the game not loading has been partially fixed; you get a pop-up allowing you to choose running the game with the older directX, thus enabling the game to load.
- The extra enemies roaming the world is really great (I am talking about the bears, wolves and so on). They present a nice challenge while you try to expand your city and helps level up your heroes and/or military units.
- A better system for equipping units is needed. It might be okay finding 10 different units to equip each and everyone, but when you get just a bit above that it becomes a nightmare, really. An auto-equipping tool or a better system for finding and selecting individual units perhaps.
In the swamp map new units keep joining your city even though you haven't build cottages to support them. While a few of these joinings can work, it needs some limit as it becomes really hard to keep up with all the new units.
- The storage system is still unlogical. There seems to be no shared limit for each resource and the storage house is missing update functions that allow for more storage.
- The city wall is missing a function that allows for upgrading from tier 1 to tier 3.
- I would really like some sort of road tool, so you can make the city look more city-like.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Right, so, it's in Early Access. This is something to keep in mind.
Secondly, it's updated infrequently, but the devs keep people up to date on what they're doing.

That said, it's honestly shaping up to be a pretty good game (in my opinion). As a city builder it's ok, maybe not the greatest thing on the planet, but it's capable. Where it really shines is the editor. The editing tool is a fairly robust mapping tool, that I love.

Lastly, I haven't put to much time into the game, so you should probably disregard my review, and read those of people who have played for a longer length of time. (Also worth noting, I bought this game when it was first released on Early Access.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wrote a review for this game back on April 2 and at the time I did not recommend this game.  It was not due b/c of poor content or lack of updates, but I felt the game had not been developed enough.  To me, it seemed that Folk Tale was missing some basic features.  Now that I am playing it again a month later; I want to update this review.

In the April review I listed a few concerns/issues that I had.  There were:
1) Lack of right clicking the screen to move the map.
2) Main resources not on the main screen.  I would have to go into menu system to view this important information.
3) Easily calling soldiers to the fight.

Here is my update, plus a few things for a wish list.

1)  Even though the devs never put in a right click and hold feature to move the map quickly like in most RTS games, they did implement a shift" function.  You still move the map with WASD keys normally.  To traverse the map more quickly
date: you still use the WASD keys but also hold shift.  At 1st I didn't know if I would like this
recommended: but I will say that this works pretty well.\n\nI have been told in the next few patches they are going to refine this feature further to give the player more control.  (Will be able to adjust speed of the camera
hoursPlayed: etc.)\n\n2) They fixed this.  The important rescores (wood
voteText: stone
helpfulPercent: iron
votesHelpful: food) are all on the main screen
votesTotal: plus more.\n\n3) This one is kind of sort of on me.  The game has yet to have a patrol function or a QRF button (quick reaction force
votesFunny: military term)  but you can group your soldiers to a number key and call them into battle that way.  One thing I did notice in my earlier review; you could only have 4 soldiers at a time.  At the time the game did not have an upgrade feature for the barracks.  As of now
commentsCount: it does and you can recruit more soldiers through upgrading the barracks.\n\nThe devs have really been listening to the community and this is a huge plus!  In fact
column16: after I wrote my 1st review
column17: I was contacted by them and they talked to me about my concerns.  Amazing!! For that and all the said updates
column18: I am now "recommending" this game!  However
column19: do realize that it is still in early access and it has been for a while and probably will stay that way till roughly early 2016 (per game page on steam).  Do not think that this is finished project.  It is not
column20: and the devs would agree.  However
column21: it is still a fun game.  Visually and audibly
column22:
the game has really set the bar in this type of genera.   I look forward to future updates and Dev Hangouts on Twitch.

Wish List:

I will update as more ideas and thoughts come to me.

Roads:  It would cool to be able to build roads in the game.  It seems like on the map there are lanterns and wall around that look like they should be on a road.  Or as you build buildings close to each other
column23: maybe a road will automatically appear.\n\nPeasants:  I am not sure if there is quicker way or not.  But having a feature where you can quickly find peasants.  I always seem to have to look around my town to locate them
column24: when I want to manually task them."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game when it was in early access a long time ago and when the game was headed in a different direction, so the current incarnation isn't what I thought the game was going to be. That being said, I am happy with the direction it has gone in, and even though it is currently incomplete, it's still a pretty fun game.

I've spent pretty much all my time playing the campaign and sandbox modes, so I haven't given the map editor a whirl yet. This game's primary focus is on village building, but all your villagers can be equipped with gear and called upon to fight, and everybody levels up. You can create soldiers and arbalists as your primary fighting force, and there are unique characters with special powers, abilities and gear. While there are plenty of enemies on the maps to make conquering it challenging, they do leave you alone for a short while so you can establish your defenses enough.

The level of involvement is great and I can't wait to see what else they add to the game. Building placement is extremely flexible, only preventing you from placing them on top of other buildings or in rivers, on cliffs, etc, so you can plan it out pretty much however you want. Even in Alphas, the game is pretty stable and I have only experienced one or two crashes. Controls and UI are pretty easy to pick up, for it being such an involved game.

My only possible complaint would be about the combat. It's cool fighting with the unique characters, since they have some special abilities, but at the moment, NPC AI is pretty bad. If there are enemies close enough, your villagers will attack automatically, so long as you don't click anything. Several times my melee fighters have let my ranged attackers get slaughtered, while they were moving from one mob to another, so you kind of need to direct them to each mob you want dead. It'd be great if there was an option to have them protect ranged units.

These devs are pretty active and seem dedicated, so I don't doubt they'll be making improvements for a while now.

Early Access Review

The game has alot of ambition and promise. The environment really stands out with its vibrant colours and very neat graphics and fluid animation.

I kept a eye on this for a while since it first came to be 'Early Access' but never purchased it until recently from seeing people play it on Twitch.

The detail the the characters are beautiful, especially when you play it on a laptop that isnt even meant for gaming. But it runs like a charm and even on low settings the game looks just as beautiful. Just to point out I am VERY fussy when it comes to games but this one definitely deserves positive feedback and a like +1.

I havent been playing it for to long but I keep finding myself coming back to it and to tell you the truth I havent had this much fun since Stonghold 2 and The Settlers series.

I really can't wait to be able to play the game once finished and fully updated. Speaking of updates they are really regular and the development team are doing a great job!.

It is alot to ask for and it makes me seem ungreatful, but seriously on a level, I very much appreciate all the time and effort the team has put into this and I am one happy customer!.


-Feedback-

There is one thing I would love to see happen though, this being, more Hero characters in one town, maybe add a inn where you can choose to hire a hero or two from a range of 10-20 characters or even be able to fully customize the looks of the Heros. :)


Keep up the impressive work guys! This game is a Gem!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a map maker, modder and big fan of user generated content, I am very optimistic about this game and what it can entail. Looking at my hours played, this should be no surprise. Although it does not directly support modding, creators can make whatever they want of the game, be it modifying the city building, or simply create a standard RPG with factions, dungeons, boss fights and loot - completely skipping the city building aspect of it. Endless hours of fun definitely awaits.

However, if you are just a player, content will be rather limited. Seeing as the entire campaign is going to be made in the editor they are giving to players. Then obviously the content has taken a hit and only 8-10% of the campaign is done (still some good hours though). You can randomize your own maps, pop in a couple of enemies and have fun fighting with them, but for a tailor made experience, you might want to wait a couple more months, wait for the campaign to be nearer completion or the integration and implementation of steam workshop.

However, as it has developed, I am quite confident that it will live up to whatever expectations you might have to a game of this genre. if you are or have a little map maker inside of you, or maybe you want to tell a funny story, buy ASAP and start creating. If you are a player looking for a finished product, either wait for completion or grab the game when it pops up on sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game takes a piece from many genres, RTS, RPG and Open-world. You have your peasants as your basic unit which you then promote or demote as needed to keep your city going. They can focus on gathering resources, resource processing, and combat. As it stands now the project has basic gameplay available - no resource processing yet but the buildings and roles are there just no logic behind them.

/workhat on
As an IT scrummaster, for a team this size working 2 years on this game it looks great. Some may complain about the lack of content up to this point but you need remember that first they need to build the world and they made some changes based on community feedback which causes rework of many of the upstream tasks, thus changing their plan. The more that support their development by purchasing the Early Access to allow them to increase team size, even with the time needed to onboard the new people it would increase their velocity.  They want their game released as bad as the rest of us but I'd rather them take a page from Blizzard's book and release it when it's done that EA that patches it when it's released. Great job guys.
/workhat off

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The mixed reviews this game has gotten are a little unfair. The reason it is like this is because development is slow, they have a small team. Don't buy this game if you want a complete and finished product, don't buy any early access games if that is what you are looking for.


That said the game is starting to get in great shape, but there is still a lot to be added. I recommend looking at their main page and roadmap for the game. They have massive plans for Folk Tale that will ensure a distinct and enjoyable game for those interested in sandbox rpg's, city building and hero development. The transparency with the development team is one of the best I have encountered, and they really are creating a quality game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I decided to ignore the negative reviews and bought the game while it was on sale.  So far, after the early may 2015 patch, I think it shows quite a bit of promise.  It's been stable, the graphics are plenty good for the type of game, and at this point, there's a reasonable diversity of buildings.

There's several things that should be added (or, if they exist, pointed out where they are):
- there needs to be a list of villagers so you can easily see how many of each kind there are, select individuals, etc.
- soldiers don't seem to have a patrol ability.  Maybe that's not implemented yet?

I'd say at this point, it's looking pretty decent.  If they can keep building on what they have, I think that they'll have a pretty decent game when it's done.

Early Access Review

I thought this may have a bit of Majesty Fantasy Kingdom but so far I have beaten off gnolls and spiders with my villagers . When I saw the upgrades in each building I was excited to think of all the different enhancements the villagers would get but unfortunately , most are just a 10% increase in efficeincy . Nothing wrong with that but , even a little variety in the upgrades would be a bit more interesting . Maybe the hunters could get increased range , butchers could get stronger with a bit more damage , same with woodcutters .... I geuss what im trying to say is when panning over the upgrades a building offers only to see 10% efficeincy on ALL of them in the upgrade window ...meh ... variety is the key ...

great game . i love it . i dont mind the slow pace at all . It can take a bit to figure out how many villagers are prone and not working ... because at first I wanted to see a ratio of villagers with no assignments and then quick key to them but it's actually not that bad whatsoever .

keep up the bug fixes . I did get an odd item off spiders , common venom sac I think but in my inventory it was just a white box ... oh well , Im going to start again because Im envisioning a different layout for my buildings .....

if you like settlers , even Majesty ,,, give this a try

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Written for 0.3.0

Fair warning now, it is early access and as the game is of this writing its little more than a watered down version of the settlers series. That being said the developers do seem to consistently produce updates and have grand dreams of what the game will be, how they intend to be different from the settlers series is not terribly clear.

Would i recommend buying it. Yes so long as you know what you are getting is far from a complete product.

There is zero single player campaign and 3 sandbox maps of different difficulty.

I am running Win 8 and only once have had a crash, aside from that the game has run flawlessly for me on max settings. There are major balance issues at hand and little to do once you have a established city. But the potential is there and thus far the developers seem  to be chugging along.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Still pretty early in the development process, but enough to have fun with.  I have spent about 8 hours on the beginner map, which still leaves me the medium and hard maps to play with.  I think it is worth the money and am excited to see the finished product.

As of May 7th, 2015 you can expect to play as one race (human) and do sandbox city building activities, with some exploration thrown in.  Most of the RPG elements are still in development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm really enjoying this game. I noticed it ages ago, so when it went on sale a few days ago, I took the plunge despite the mixed reviews. I'm glad I did. I can see Folk Tale becoming one of my all-time favorites.

I've played city builders since early Caesar, and plenty of RPGs. The art is cute and really crisp. I love the look of my village, and the various looks of the upgraded buildings (only gotten to level 2 so far, though). I feel like I've barely scratched the surface, and am looking forward to getting into the RPG aspects more.

I know it's not finished, but I have my own list of things I would love to see improved sooner rather than later:

-- Labor management needs fine-tuning. There needs to be an easy way to list all the villagers, and see who is working where, so you can spread out the workforce the way you want it when there's a population downturn. Plus, It's virtually impossible to find your peasant. Yes, you can click on any building an see him or her on the left, as the lone unemployed person, but the Find button doesn't work for this person. Also, who is living in which houses? (Less critical, but could be fun.)

-- The odd language choices confuse me. Yes, on nom nom" is a cutesy way of saying "eat"
date: but it looks like gibberish on the screen. Worse is "very work
recommended: much happy" which appears under every character's mini portrait in the building menu. Very weird -- it made me think the game was being made by non-English speakers
hoursPlayed: but the studio is based in London. King's English
voteText:
people! Another suggestion: lose the "some" in the activity status -- because "retrieving some bolt of cotton" is grammatically incorrect and bugs.

-- The buttons around an individual's portrait are confusing. What is the brain-like thing that has a dotted green line around it? I didn't see it mentioned in the Tutorial. Add the job title to these mini portraits -- they now appear only if you click on an individual's inventory. That's really tedious. I want to click on a person and see their job title immediately.

-- It would be nice to be able to cycle through your citizens so you could quickly put extra armor and whatnot on them. Also
helpfulPercent: I'm tired of seeing the same guy's face
votesHelpful: even for the women. He's not even cute.\n\n-- When a villager is sick
votesTotal: a green cloud appears around him or her
votesFunny: but there's nothing in their personal information that says they're infected (or what with
commentsCount: which would be a nice detail).\n\n-- Any chance of a time fast forward? That green expansion bar moves really slowly
column16: even after you've corrected an error. It takes a long time for the changes to take effect. This is normal for city-building games
column17: but most of those have pauses and fast fowards.\n\n-- I can't figure out a good way to use my troops. There's no real patrol function
column18: since they don't respond to attacks unless you tell them to. I tried posting them on the borders -- that helped some
column19: but they still seem pretty ineffective. Also
column20:
it's not clear (to me yet) how you can have both melee and rangers in the same barracks. Seems to be an either/or? I admit I haven't fully researched this -- I hope a future Tutorial will delve into town defense.

-- I found some villagers doing tasks unrelated to their jobs? (Like harvesting carrots when they're a fisherman.) Is this intended?

-- The resources totals at the top don't seem to go past 1000 -- even the town gold. I know I had more than 1000 coins
column22: but the number never changed. I'm not sure if I got credit for the money or not. I assume it's a bug and not a real cap. For another resource
column24: the inventory pane showed more than 1000
column25: but the top bar didn't.\n\n-- After playing for awhile
column27: items show up as white boxes.\n\n-- What does the woodcutter do once all the trees are cut down? Supposedly I got some tree seeds
column28: but I have no idea how to use them.\n\n-- I wish there were scenarios
column29: ones that gradually increase in difficulty
column30: like in Tropico or Caesar IV. And more building options (as in variety of buildings).\n\nI'm very excited by all the possibilities with this game. I hope it all comes to pass -- the city-building genre needs some great new titles."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, not bad with what they've got so far. Pretty diverse selection of buildings and needs, plays sort of like the Settlers. They have, however, gone several significant changes in mechanics and city building over time (the tutorial itself is different than the rest), and a major negative at the moment is no saving sandbox worlds. Overall, needs polish and some core features like the campaign and saves implemented before you could consider it a game.

I'd say wait for now and buy it when on sale for the potential it's got.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has truly come a long way since it first launched and since I first bought it. I know this is going to be an excellent game when it is done. It had gone from a test of the game engine basically up to the status it is now which is much more immersive. Fans of city builders and rpg adventure would do well to buy this game and join in influencing how you want to see the game develop. You can even create your own maps. When this game is completed you are going to be kicking yourself and wondering why you didn't get it for that cheaper price earlier on. Sure plenty of people have been burned with games that were early access and never saw completion, however, this Dev team is dedicated to what they are doing and come out with regular updates and fixes to the existing game. (Written around alpha 16)

Keep in mind that it is still in Early Access. So if you are looking for a lot of playability immediatley, you won't get that right now. But a lot of recent updates to the game are culminating into what will be a large increase in playability and content. I am truly more excited for this game then any Triple A title or any other game for that matter. (Alpha 22.3) (0.3.2.3)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a lot of potential in the way of sorytelling, visual theme, and developer interaction. Unfortunately, it is still very far from obtaining the gem they wish to create, and could possibly take too long. From what I've gathered, the focus of the game is currently being shifted toward a less scripted sandbox mechanic as proposed by overwhelming popular majority(I think). Also, the amount of features required to give this game any replayability is quite daunting for a team of this size, and as a result they will be facing a very long roadmap. In any case, I always have support for dedicated developers, and I hope they will continue to hold costumer feedback in the highest regards. For these reasons I have personally invested in their vision, and will be an active contributor if development continues. I would expect others to understand that you will not be paying for a very long period of play, but it could possibly become an engaging and extensive game in a couple painstaking years. If you don't want to throw money at the situation like i have, then at least keep an eye on it for a sale of some kind, or an update that really seals this economy pinch they're in.
-Thanks for reading!
voteText: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the current stage the game is fun to play.

It is a mix of city builder with RPG elements.

There is one fundamentally nice thing - in other games as Your population grows, their deamands also grow and if suddenly You run out of certain supplies - You have the game end because everyone leaves or dies.

Here it is a bit more balanced - You will be noticed about lacking resources but Your village will not die out - the happiness and some other attributes will degrade, but You still have a chance to recover.

I really like this aproach.

There are rough edges and bugs, but nothing game breaking.

Love it.  Yes, it's early access but it's really good!  There is still enough functionality to have a good time.  The devs are very responsive and continually working on the game, so you know your feedback is being listened to and incorporated.

I wouldn't recommend paying $29 for it, I got it during the 40% of sale and even then was apprehensive about bying an early access game with  mixed reviews.  However it's been worth the $20 or so I paid.  Can't say with certainty that it's worth $29 though, sorry!

If you're looking for a full on campaign to play through with more features then you can shake a stick at then you might want to go play the new Anno game while you wait for this one to be finished.  Otherwise get in there, get invovled and help make it into something really special.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just bought the game on May 5th, 2015 so I have not played a lot yet. I will update when I put more time in, but so far I enjoy the game. Lets keep in mind I bought it even though there are mixed reviews. It is an early access game that has been early access for a long time, but so are many other games I currently play. To me that isn't a deal breaker so long as there have been updates made.

----------------------------------------------------

It reminds me of Banished, but adds another layer to your townspeople that was lacking. I like that I can research new armor to equip onto each person and learn new ways to make my farming or mining more successful. It feels like I have many more options to customize my town how I want. Plus there is even combat and looting!

I was confused at first how I was supposed to find anyone in my town when I needed lets say my Hunter. Reading reviews this was a major concern to others as well. After a little while I did figure out a simple way in locating anyone that is assigned to a building. Just go to that building and it will list your workers with a little button that selects them. Not the easiest way ever. This isn't something pointed out to you in the tutorial either, so I am guessing there is plenty more that I will have to discover for myself.

Even still I like the look of the game and the music as well. The voices used are pretty solid, but don't vary a ton.

I am looking forward to future updates and playing the game more myself to get a better feel for it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the few games in greenlight that I have purchased that actually works, to a degreen and is well made enough to have the smoothest voice bloke doing the tutorial.

I will say there are a few things I enjoyed:

1. the style - visually impressive and not bad when zoomed in all the way
2. the resource tree - great idea of having ANN0 styled production trees
3. variety of enemies and the the variet eney types and models.
4. building placement - Love it that you can place structures anywhere, no grid or snap mechanics that constrict creativity.

I will say here that there are areas that need improving

1. speed upa nd slow down functinallity
2. larger maps with more resources
3. items in the inventory showing up as white boxes
4. the storehouse not having employees and also would be a great place to hire dedicated item trasporting workers like the teamsters office in Tropico
5. group wide item distribution or customer templates for civs to have put on them
6. more in depth city building and customisation - only scratching the surfice, you could have guilds, temples, grand halls more item manufacturing for later in the game with specifi reasources.

These are all just suggenstions as the game is only in early access but thought I'd throw my thoughts in.

Early Access = Alpha. Don't expect a finished game. But it does look very promising!

Either way, I've had fun and am now waiting for the tower defense mini game part that they want to release next and, of course, hope to get my hands on the finished game.

If you don't want to buy an unfinished game that doesn't really let you play anything yet, don't buy this. But if you like what you see, follow it and see how it develops and then make another choice of buying or not buying when it's ready.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My advice: Get it now
This game is beautiful. It can be compared to banished BUT IT IS DIFFERENT
**I cannot stop playing**
Banished is a very difficult and tedious game... but this is completely different because of a few things.
- You control the population
- Resource collecting in general is less of a chore and more of a joy
- Crafting
- Loot from enemies
- Fighting, which I'll get into here
- Enemies spawn in groups across the map. There are even enemy strongholds
- You build barracks to make soldiers
- Anyone can fight but they ^ are the best
- There are bears, wolverine-like clawed monsters, spiders and their nests, enemies weilding axes, etc.
- Research can be performed increasing the efficiency and benefits of all the buildings (they are all different)
- Huge impressive defensive walls can be built
- You can make a gate anywhere in the wall
- You can mount crossbows on the wall towers to fend off invaders
-----------It's early access... there's so much more coming!
The few cons (I'm not listing things that are not implemented like potion ingredients because it will become irrelevant eventually)
- Disease spreads like wildfire, and while it's not devestating at all if you manage it, the narrator announces whenever someone becomes sick which is often
- Some may say the spiders come too frequently, but if you take out the nest they will stop coming. They sort of patrol around it. (A fun feature for me but maybe annoying to some who don't want to fight)
- I can't think of any other cons

This is just a beautiful, original (as far as I can tell) and addicting game. The balance is unmatched by anything else out there right now with the addition of rpg fighting mechanics and strategic placements of guards and walls.
My advice: Get it now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The progress made over the last couple months on this game has been outstanding.  I initially purchased it right out of the gates and only dabbled in it.  I was happy to take part in the early access concept because this style of game play appeals to me.  Now I am extremely happy to have finally returned to the title to take a peek at all that's happened since those early first steps.  Very excited about how the new sandbox play operates and extremely encouraged by what I've seen so far.  I know find myself wondering...how much longer? HOW MUCH LONGER for the next patch lol!

The simple way to look at this game is, if you enjoy city builders, if you enjoyed the Settlers and the Anno series, then this is the style of game that is right up your alley...AND add to that some more in depth RPG elements.  I was initially concerned with the direction of the game early on but am now very very pleased with where it's at and where it's going.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a quick review regarding Alpha version 0.3.0.  Got this on a Steam sale for $14.99.  Honestly, it was an impulse buy after a crappy day at work.  At a glance, it looked fun, thought I might play for an hour or so then call it quits, like with most early release games I buy.  They provide a nice distraction, but I rarely get hooked.

Folk Tale, however, did not disappoint.  I'm still playing it, and can't seem to get enough.  Even at this early stage.

It should be noted that my girlfriend and myself, who are both playing it, are huge fans of the Fable series by Lionhead (except for Legends...whats that even about?!).  We love the setting, the characters, the humor, the art, all of it.  So Folk Tale is a natural fit for us.  Its a beautiful fantasy setting where everything has tons of character.  The buildings are unique and stand out amoung the beautifully rendered landscapes.  The people who live in your town are fun to watch as they go about their day doing their thing, whatever that is that you assign them to.  The interface is intuitive, but offers a ton of complexity if you want to get down and dirty.  Once I found that I could even start assigning clothes and armor to my townfolk I was completely enamored.  I imagine you could just play from a 50,000-foot level and just manage a-la 'god sim' or get down and really micromanage each and every one of your townfolk.

Personally, I love a good sim where I can make my townfolk happy and prosperous, and the idea that I can send them off on quests and watch as my world becomes a kingdom...well...I'm hooked.  It's fun, easy to learn, but complicated and with enormous depth, and they still have a ways to go, which to me means it's only going to become more and more awesome!  I love where it's going, and can't wait to see what's next.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So many unnecessary bad reviews!!! This is not just a game but a game within game creation software!!! It is almost unfair to call it a game. I swore to myself after so many abandon ware or early access quiters or whatever kind of crap game rip off that comes along i was not going to buy" another game. Most of the bad reviews mainly discuss the 2 years in early access. Yes i agree that 2 years is a little long for early access but... the producer is small and METICULOUS so deserves a little slack. o.k. i did not buy this game 2 years ago so maybe my frustration level is not as high as someone who did; but all you have to do is mess around with this "system/game/what have you" and you will see the potential this title has. I look at it like this; if you have a game that allows modding or level development you have a virtual unlimited game. Add to this that mod levels are often better than the developers. Look what the world has given us with the Bethesda products! Skyrim is 5 years old and is still relevant in any current game of the year discussion. This title has not reached that level but it has the possibility. As far as updates to this game?? After i promised to not "buy" any other games i started to keep an eye on this one. I started in January and by May there were significant additions and changes to this title so that i decided to break my decision and purchase this game.  I am not sorry i did...

btw i have significantly more time in this title than is illustrated."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From other reviews, I see that this game has been in development for quite some time, but I just got it after the newest update. This game is obviously unfinished, and not all features work yet; none the less,I have greatly enjoyed playing it so far. The graphics are cute, and I like all the little snippets that people say when I order them about. Equipping items is not working all the way, and this makes fighting all about mobbing the enemies that are sitting around the map.

I would recommend this game, but really impatient people might want to wait until it has been updated a few more times.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is in early access, but for how far I've seen it come since I first started playing it until now, I know this will be a PC classic. Same as Age of Empires, or Rise of Nations. There is clearly a spin on it, a different approach, that obviously still needs some tweaking and other additions. Really great new engine and concept, to an age old genre. I do recommend this game if you enjoy a unique twist on city developement/RTS games, with enough familiarity that you don't feel lost.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I enjoy this game a lot and its only in its Alpha stage.  There are quirks just like in any Alpha game but the dev community is always listening, responding, and has updates monthly.   Most EA games dont have that on here at all.  I am not a fan boy of anyone game, there are games I like and games I dislike, but the potential for this game is amazing.

So, basically this game is like any other settles game at first.  Its basic management and survival ... food, shelter and security then go out and beat up others take their stuff. Ah but here is where it gets good.  You dont just build an army to go out and pick on people no you get an adventuring party!  So the chaos enues from there as you beat up monsters, dens, and dungeons and slowly build up your buildings and village.  so this is all fine and all but while I reccomend this game I have one question for the devs.

End game?  What is the proposed end game?  Will the village get so big it dies off. thats not reasonable.   Maybe when a village gets so large it starts off and sends out a new group to a new area, like starcraft style?  That would be great then you might even get support from your other village and build it up too.  So thats my only concern with this game, what will be the endgame to it.  Could you imagine the workshop options you could have here?

Other than that this is a great time suck game and I have killed lots of hours playing it and replaying it.  I hope you like it to and please see it for what it is and not the Alpha errors everyone gets it, its in Alpha ... Thanks for reading!

I bought this game going on two years now and left it to grow mold in my library. When I first bought it you had specific spots you could put your buildings and a very linear story; not only could you not save your game but the game also did not save itself.

I opened this game the other day and wasn't sure if it was the same game I was thinking of. It has an AoE feel to it now and is a playable game. It still has bugs, as expected; it is still lacking some functions, as expected. The one major feature I am hoping for is a random gen map and/or Steam Workshop to download other players' created maps.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review

In short, if there was a strategy game where you built and managed the towns/cities in Fable, this would be the game.

As of writing this review, the game has a very solid foundation of chains and development. It took me about 3 hours to wipe out all the creep camps on the Easy map, have one of each production chain maxxed out, and about 100 villagers. After that, there was really nothing to do (I couldn't build more units, move to a new territory, craft better gear, etc.) However, if I could have kept upgrading/expanind, I definitely would have. Granted, I haven't played any more difficult maps, so there could be a greater level of depth already built into this pre-release.

Overall Mechanics: Economy is similiar to Banished with a bit more depth. You construct a town that provides for typical basic needs of any citizens in an RTS, as well as gold/stone/iron etc. While you can assign villagers to different jobs, they essentially do the rest from there (you have the option to micro manage, but why bother). You can upgrade buildings to allow a greater workforce, as well as research technologies for each building. (Level 1 building = 4 workers, lvl 2 = 8, lvl 3 = 12; each building has 3-8 technologies that basically increase the gather range or add xx% to production). Right now, the most in depth production chain is about three buildings/layers deep (wheat farm [wheat] -> windmill [flour] -> bakery [bread]). Once you build a barracks, you can train archers or halberdiers (ranged or melee units) and use the blacksmith to outfit them with equipment. You can research recipes at the blacksmith and find better ones in the wild. Basic resources come from your organic production, whereas the more advanced ones are found after clearing creep camps.

Glitches: I did experience a few crashes, but they only seemed to occur as I was exiting back to windows anyway, so it didn't matter. There were some issues when I'd craft/find an item, it would show up in my inventory as a blank box that I could not inspect or equip. The only villager AI isues I came across so far was when I was building the advanced walls, they would sit there and construct" for the rest of the game
date: which meant my production buildings would not longer recruit them since this never-ending-construction seemed to take them out of the available labor pool. Clicking on the mini-map would direct me to a random place on the map
hoursPlayed: very minor issues that I am sure can be easiliy fixed.\n\nBalancing Issues: stockpiling stone/planks/iron/gold was fairly simple and quick
voteText: but I continuously had a problem keeping enough of the consumables on hand. Even when the bread production chain was fully upgraded/maxxed out (36 villagers in a population of about 90)
helpfulPercent: I constantly ran out of bread. I was also constantly out of meat
votesHelpful: fish
votesTotal: and vegetables. While not so much a balancing issue
votesFunny: I could not find a "find idle worker" button. This would have been handy when I wanted to specifically recruit only archers
commentsCount: as the auto-recruit for the barracks produces a mix of archers and halberdiers.\n\nOverall
column16: this was a pretty fun game. I think it has a decent amount of potential. It has a great environment (again - it reminds me of Fable
column17: specifically Oakvale) The devs have clearly made a solid foundation from which to continue to add depth. I look forward to future updates."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got this game back when it first was released as an early access and I will admit that the progress has been very slow and I stopped playing it for a while. I came back and so many things were different but the way it has gone has been a major improvement to what it was before. If they released the early access where the game is now they would not have so much of a mixed review.  Well now into the pros and cons:

Pros
- Not every faction is an enemy
- Easy construction system
- Make your own maps
- The appearance

Cons
- No tutorial (they used to have one for the old system)
- Little confusing to get started

Suggestions
- A random map generator would be amazing for it
- A better way for villagers to come (something like a birth system)

I am looking forward to see how this game develops over time because it has so much potential I just wish they would make it a little bit faster.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To say the least, This is not the same game that was originally released in early access. Indeed, still early access, but nearly no resemblance to the turd nugget that it once was. THIS game, that you will get if you download today, has some great potential. It's clever and, in some areas, already polished.

I hope the developers continue down this path, I'm quite excited to see how it turns out.

Definitely worth looking at if you are interested in an old timey city builder with some serious RPG slants. There are a lot of negative comments on this game, but mainly due to the crap sandwich this game use to be. If you look at recent reviews, you'll see that the reviews have come nearly as far as this game in the right direction.

In conclusion, This is a pretty great game that was pretty bad when it first came out. So give it another chance or a first chance, you be glad you did.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is marked as an alpha release I know that it is not intended to be a finished product but it is effectively unplayable.  It's more like a custom warcraft III map that nobody got around to finishing.  I spent several hours building a village with upgraded versions of all of the production buildings.  Eventually at a population of around 100 sickness will begin spreading and you will run out of medicine no matter what you do.  Your villagers will never be happy.  I made a fully upgraded monastary and tavern right next to eachother with a well and several beehives.  the monks stock piled thousands of honeycombs and produced mead far too slowly for my village even with 15 monks working and all research completed.  Don't try to make doubles of any of your production structures either if you do your villagers will inevitably be to far from a needed resource.  Villagers need to be in the area of a resources building to pick it up and if heir cottage is too far from say, the tailor's place they will be low on clothes even if the tailor has a stockpile

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Folk Tale has changed a lot since my first review, so I decided to give it another chance.

Whilst I didn't exactly fall in love, I feel quite strongly that the game has a lot of promise. It's very, very good-looking, has a great soundtrack, and an appealing UI. Playing it is very soothing - it's very smooth to play, and I reallllly enjoy the graphic style. It reminds me a lot of The Settlers series. I'm really surprised to find an alpha indie game looking this good.

Folk Tale still has some way to go, with plenty of stuff still to implement, but it's definitely worth looking at if you're into this type of game. Everything that is implemented so far looks professional and I came away with the feeling like the game is now being developed by competent people. If they can make the gameplay and complexity to the same standard as the art direction, then this will be a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Concept is a lot like Empire.  You build using settlers and huts to increase settlers.  I like the medieval twist using Kobalds and quests (Though I have yet to be able to do any quests.)  graphics are pretty cool, nothing great. Some big issues thus far though. 1:  The adviser who says you need more bread or meat or whatever, never stops once it starts and repeats every second.  There needs to be a way to turn that off.  2: You need to VASTLY improve the skill levels to match each accordingly.  Right now even on training level it is nearly impossible to learn or improve your village.  That's ridiculous.  Training level shouldn't need advisors beyond that of the actual training and frankly shouldn't have any worries at all as training level should strictly be a learning level ONLY..  You should be able to build anything and you should never lose settlers.  The next level, the beginners equivelent should only be slightly harder, needing a timy bit of food and maybe losing settlers only after having no food for like 30 minutes or something.  Then tweak the higher levels accordingly.    3:  When you send a Villager to do something they dance around at the spot for a few minutes before doing anything, wasting valuable time you have to gather resources and build things.

Overall the concept is pretty cool and has the potential to be a pretty decent hit but much work needed yet before it's really playable for any length of time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The progress made over the last couple months on this game has been outstanding.  I initially purchased it right out of the gates and only dabbled in it.  I was happy to take part in the early access concept because this style of game play appeals to me.  Now I am extremely happy to have finally returned to the title to take a peek at all that's happened since those early first steps.  Very excited about how the new sandbox play operates and extremely encouraged by what I've seen so far.  I know find myself wondering...how much longer? HOW MUCH LONGER for the next patch lol!

The simple way to look at this game is, if you enjoy city builders, if you enjoyed the Settlers and the Anno series, then this is the style of game that is right up your alley...AND add to that some more in depth RPG elements.  I was initially concerned with the direction of the game early on but am now very very pleased with where it's at and where it's going.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFolk Tale is a game that had the potential to be one of the best city builders ever. The art was a fresh detour from the norm, and the RPG aspect gave the game a more active feel. It is because of these specific things and all the pontential that I'm sad to say: this game has no direction. When is say that, I don't mean it has no direction in the sense that it lacks an attainable goal, nor do I mean that it is akin to Minecraft--the game that made directionless fun popular; Folk Tale is somewhere between what the devs said they were doing, and what a niche in the community wanted. This game doesn't deliver an immersive city building experience--in a fantasy setting, because of an impotent AI that doesn't work half the time; however, Folk Tale also doesn't deliver on its adopted promise to be a great sandbox game, because it has a particular fantasy, RPG/RTS feel to it that requires a strong, immersive base to stand alone in the sandbox enviroment. Even when you ignore the broken AI, odd development choices, and lack of clear direction, Folk Tale still suffers from a start/stop update cycle that adds incomplete, often empty features; during my time in Folk Tale it was common for me to come across a menu option, or tab and be met with not avalible in this version of Folk Tale." The worst instance of this came when I attempted to change the scroll speed in-game; I quickly discovered that the control menu didn't exist
date: but the menu tab for controls was present.\n\nAll things considered
recommended: I can ignore the fact that this game isn't what I originally paid for
hoursPlayed: that it still isn't even close to being a true playable beta
voteText: or even that many pieces of the current build are either broken/barely working. The reason I can't reccomend this game is because the developers lied; the developers lied--and continue to lie--because they refuse to admit that they've messed up. The developers pretend  that everything is as it should be
helpfulPercent: and that the game is progressing steadily; the truth is that this game will likely never be released
votesHelpful: and if it is will likely be riddled with bugs and unfinished content. Today I gave this game a final chance to impress me after waiting almost a full year for it to be developed more. Today I finally let go of any final hope that Folk Tale will be anything to me
votesTotal: but another reason I don't trust or wish to support indie developers.\n\nIn my humble opinion I would not reccomend purchasing this game
votesFunny: even once released--if it ever is--I would strongly advise anyone to steer clear of it.\n\nDo not waste your money."
