reviewText:
Early Access Review

tldr; Highly recommend supporting this game if you're into early access (I.e. the game is not yet finished), enjoy the genre and like supporting true indie titles.

Helpful staff that was easy to get into contact when finding a bug during early early access (I spoke to a developer through Steam Chat directly when it first released -- which impressed me that he took the time out of his day -- with regards to fixing a problem / bug I had with the game).  Frequent updates on website pertaining what their goals are next.  Good changes and ideas implemented from when the game was initially placed on Early Access.  In addition, you can look for yourself on the steam discussion forums how much they have interacted with the playerbase.

Definitely a game that they keep working on and haven't abandoned; statistics show they hired more people to their small team some time ago.  Granted, such was researched by myself last year and I haven't the time to do such lately.  However, they frequently release videos and updates on their website located at:  http://www.gamesfoundry.com/default.aspx

Sandbox mode is fairly fun to partake in.  The game's future overall looks bright.  Hoping early reviews of the early access campaign won't affect them too much when they finally have a working released version.  The RPG village builder idea also seems to be coming along quite nicely.

When it comes to the actual content of the game, I will not make mention.  It's early access, and things will change.  Their website has many videos, and there are other who have their opinions on the matter.  In addition, there many be many videos online, though most of those are from the early edition of early access when it first released.  The game has since be vastly updated with new technology and is no longer limited to the tutorial (and there are no longer building placement restrictions outside of said tutorial).

This review is of my opinion on April 10th, 2015.  Most of my gameplay time is from early, early access and late last year.  If you're into supporting development teams, this is a good one to invest in.  I'm constantly coming back to look at updates out of interest.  In addition, the game developer seems to be open to criticism -- as most should be -- to ultimately make for a better product in the end.

I picked this game up on a 40% off sale figuring since I loved city builders I might as well give it a shot. To be honest it wasn't exactly what i was expecting. The small RTS elements in this city bulder were new and exciting for me but some bugs and a lack of features implemented stopped me from fully enjoying myself.

I'm giving this game a thumbs up because while still somewhat buggy, it's early access and has a lot of potential. I can see how some people would find it worrysome that this has been in development for over two years but the developers are still highly active and that to me proves they don't plan to just abandon it but rather will make it into something special. If the game ever reaches completion then the 16$ CDN i paid for it was a steal.  that said I probably will wait a few months before opening this bad boy back up and seeing where it's headed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is marked as an alpha release I know that it is not intended to be a finished product but it is effectively unplayable.  It's more like a custom warcraft III map that nobody got around to finishing.  I spent several hours building a village with upgraded versions of all of the production buildings.  Eventually at a population of around 100 sickness will begin spreading and you will run out of medicine no matter what you do.  Your villagers will never be happy.  I made a fully upgraded monastary and tavern right next to eachother with a well and several beehives.  the monks stock piled thousands of honeycombs and produced mead far too slowly for my village even with 15 monks working and all research completed. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Folk Tale is a fun city builder that puts you in the role of creating a town in order to help the citizens of the countryside recover after being exploited by bandits. You set off on your journey as you build lumber mills and stone works to collect the necessary resources for further your construction. Firewood, food, clothing, mead and many others resources are just a few of the things your citizens will want as you progress to a higher Culture rating. Your culture rating will determine the current needs of your people and when they will ask for the next set of items to keep them happy and working, fail to anticipate there needs could spell doom for your town, but be ever watchful as there are enemies all about just wanting for their time to take your city down. A RPG style of hero leveling allows for your characters to grow with you as you explore and build your way to victory.

Pros:

-	The beautiful graphics and music pulls you into the game and adds that immersion feeling as you delve ever deeper.
-	The story is both well written and quite humorous at times, allowing you to grow a bond for the characters you control and care what happens to them as you make choices that will change the story line.
-	The multiple choices you are presented with that can change the story from one play through to the next allow for the replay value to be quite high and very enjoyable.
-	The controls of the game are quite easy to manage and allow for a very close view of your towns people or a high up god like view of your entire village.
-	A simple at first building technique that opens up and becomes much more detailed as your understanding of the game grows, allowing for novice and expert players alike to find something here they can enjoy.

Cons:

-	The game is still in early access so you are bound to find a bug or two from time to time. This isn’t so much a con as it is just a fact and often times doesn’t even factor into taking any of enjoyment away that’s to be had in the game.

In conclusion, Folk Tale is a fun city builder that will take you through a journey you won’t soon forget, hours of fun building your cities will make your time here both enjoyable for those who like combat and for those who don’t. 4 out of 5.
AC-Gamer

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was hesitant to buy another Early Access game, but I'm glad I got this one. Although you can tell it is far from finished, what is available in terms of gameplay is enjoyable. So far this is a sandbox village builder with a little army building/combat.

The presence of good voice acting and polished graphics/UI is something I have missed with indie games and makes it feel like a quality project in the works. I really like being able to zoom in up close and watch the villagers go about their lives. Your military villagers have inventories and take upgraded gear and weapons, and I look forward to seeing that fully implemented.

Micromanaging resource production is neat, though on the easy map not really necessary as there is no challenge to keeping up resources. At this time there are 3 maps to play in sandbox mode and they are not randomly generated yet. That will be a nice feature to see.

As far as drawbacks, it's too early to start critiquing. If I had to come up with a gripe it would be that the game can feel a little slow and it would be nice to have a hotkey to speed things up occasionally rather than tweaking it in settings. I also could not sit through the tutorial, but after skipping to sandbox it didn't take long to figure everything out with trial and error.

I am excited to see where this game goes and the activity and responsiveness of the devs gives me hope that this could end up a really fun game at completion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first review I have ever written, and I was compelled to write it to make sure people who are interested in this game feel confident in supporting it despite the (currently) mixed reviews.

I thoroughly enjoyed the tutorial when I first purchased this game, but as the devs focused on the sandbox mode I was hesistant to give it much of a go.  Most of the negative reviews are people who weren't happy with this decision, as I initally was.  After spending some time in sandbox mode, I can see that this game is still going to be something unique and intersting.  With the sandbox genre getting beat to death by developers over the last few years, Folk Tale is a breath of fresh air and a fascinating perspective on the genre.

The resource gathering is challenging but understandable and logical.  The sense of humor is on point but not over-the-top.  The RPG elements of crafting, equipping, and experience for the villagers are unlike any other game I have played.  While only having spent 3 hours playing as of writing this game, each time I return to it I am greeted by improvements and new and fun mechanics to learn.

Despite how interesting and intriguing the game itself is, the main point I wanted to make in writing this review is that this game will make you feel rewarded for supporting the developers in Early Access.  They are accessible, focused, responsive, and provide a great sense of involvement and community in the developing of this game.  Early Access can be messy, it can be fun, but it the case of Folk Tale, participating in Early Access is as much of an adventure as the game is.  Trust me, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI definetly have to recommend this game, i got it at the very early stages and i had to say that the game itself was decent it was humorus with the lack of toast in the game.... The game mechanics have gotten updated and made the game more challenging and the amount of buildings and how the economic system in the game have become make the game just that more interesting reminding me of a stronghold mixed with age of empires online feel as the game uses the same popularity scale as stronghold but has the ransacking destruction of age of empires online when your villages are big enough and you go questing. The tundra and swamp maps are pretty challenging if you dont understand the game at first because of the lack of resources or even the amount of orcs coming at you all at once. Overall this game is a very fun game, very humorous and has tons of potential and i cannot wait until the game is completed! One thing i hope for is a added multiplayer option where you can build and compete against your friends in a rival trade town.

Cons of buying this game early:

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought this game this morning.  I've played for about 9 hours so far.  I maxed out everything in my village and have killed just about everything on the map.  It seems when you chop down trees you have to replant with seeds.  So far the only way I found to obtain seeds is to kill monsters.  Eventually the monsters no longer respawn and then you can't find any more seeds.  So you wind up running out of firewood, and your villagers declare that your village sucks (literally) and start to leave.  I was unable to find a way to reverse the mass exodus, and became frustrated.  I really want to like this game, and I hope eventually I will when the devs finish with it.  Right now it just seems there's no way to sustain a permanent village in sandbox mode, and that's unfortunate.  I am going to give this game a thumbs up regardless in hopes that things will change soon.  Its worth the $15 I paid for it on sale.  I wouldn't pay much more than that though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend more buildings. It feels way too similar to the standard Banished buildings. What about playing other factions and seeing how their builds are? Their way of society? Different heroes? Other races? Humans are too plain cause it's all the same. More military and civilian structures would be nice.

Aside from that, the idea for the game is a 10/10.
I'll continue to edit the review as more things are updated to the game.

Things found...
1. When Willow stuns Gregory, his animation stops. O.0
2. Skirmish mode for hunters? They die too easily.
3. Resources for leather are very limited in beginning. Wolves and deer don't respawn as much to even
collect their fur; to build the structure for clothing in time; before peasents begin leaving.
4. (Fixed) During Tutorial, when the dialog comes up, camera and selection is disabled until player finishes dialog. This hinders doing things one step at a time during the tutorial for the speed of learners.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is super fun! they blend several genres into one soo well. im not a huge fan on city builder RTS games but this game blends RPG elements into the mix and i love it!
The project lead has weekly streams to give overview of new features, answer player's questions, and give sneak peaks at future features curently in development and direction they are going.
The community involvment the developers take is unheard of in AAA titles and will even scrap a feature if players have issues with it. they have a clear timeline for future features and will look into any recomendations that the community gives if it has enough support and makes sence.
the graphics are realy good kinda inbetween WoW and TES Skyrim, The animations are smooth and high quality. the camera contols take a bit to master at first but becomes easer the more you use them. the main gameplay has a slight learning curve to master with enimy atacks and exploration. the map designer is amazing  its easy to pick up and learn and the ability to make any landscape you want and play on the map is the best. the turrain is tile based not mesh so you cant fine tune certain aspects but the developers have included ALOT of tiles for many map features and have incuded props to add extra feartures you can add by hand.
So I would recommend this game to anyone interested in the concept of a RPG-RTS game and would recomend watching the streams and go to the forums if your unsure, but you wont regret it.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhen I first got this game in Early Access, I was intrigued. Not a lot was implemented, but I wanted to see where the game would go. After letting it sit for a while, I decided to pick it back up, and I've been pleasently surprised with how far the game has come. There's still a lot to be implemented, but this is a fun game overall. The graphics are good and the economy is fairly well balanced. The crafting system as of this review is still fairly basic, but both it and the building upgrade systems add depth. The music is quite nice and certainly adds to the experience. My one knock against the game so far is that the military units you can recruit are weak and, even with some in game improvements (armor and weapons), they do not stack up well to your opponents. So, while it's still very much a work in progress, it's a very playable, enjoyable work in progress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I waffled on getting this game because of the mixed reviews, but then it went on sale, and I read some of the more recent reviews, and I bought in.

TLDR; BEST DECISION. DO BUY.

The art style is great and cartoony and rich, the tutorial is very straight forward and helpful in getting you very comfortable with the controls and aspects of a successful town.
I'm using the beta build and I've had no crashes, just the occasional bug report pop-up.
It mixes the resource and micro-management that I love in Banished with a light RPG touch, complete with dungeon crawling missions and the ability to skill-up and equip your hero how you prefer.

My ONLY complaint is that the campaign is incomplete - I want more! I got as far as possible in it and am looking supremely forward to more content being added, more dungeons and more campaigns.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The developers adapt according to player feedback. They are very transparent and you can always check them out on Twitch.tv
http://www.twitch.tv/gamesfoundry
Originally posted by Games Foundry:From a project management and commercial point of view, the way we have to run an Early Access project is somewhat different than more traditional projects. We have to be extremely agile with a fluid project plan that isn't always optimal:

a) to be able to recognise and react to collective player feedback that may require entire modules to be rewritten;

b) to respond to a constantly changing customer environment. Receiving negative feedback did lead to a reevaluation of project task priorities, resulting in a drive to deliver playable game mechanics above all else; This can be sub-optimal from a production efficiency standpoint, but highly desirable from a commercial standpoint; We've also had to increase transparency, frequency and volume of communication in response to the needs of the wider Early Access community due to growing concern surrounding crowd funding and some failed or ethically questionable titles in Early Access.

c) to rapidly adapt to new learning in what is a very new approach to game development; Early Access is still very young as a process and mistakes are being made, but very quickly learned from.

This is definitely the most agile project I've run, with scope changing fairly regularly but in a managed way so that we can remain on track and on budget.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game a while back, and was sad that my computer couldn't run it, as it didn't have enough  RAM. But now that I've upgraded, I thought I'd leave a review.
Overall, it's a great game, with humor, and the perfect kind of gameplay for me.
I did have one problem though, and that's just how fast people start leaving when you don't have resources. For example, I had a thriving community of about thirty five people, and all of a sudden the want for mead arised, and before I knew it, all but six people had up and left. Other than that, it's a great game that I enjoy.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game back in June of 2013. Immedietaly after buying it I regretted it. That version of the game was bad. Now, fast forward to March of 2016. I decided to download it again after having not touching it for almost 3 years, due to the new screenshots I saw on the store page. I have been playing it for about 2 hours now and wow have they improved this game. The combination of village building, equipment to be found and equipped on everybody (villagers too), and dungeon exploration with your heroes is great! It reminds me of the early Settlers games, or the old game Knights and Merchants.

Pros:
Nice graphics
Fully customizable characters
Free building, build where ever is the best spot for the building
Dungeon/Cave exploration is a good break from the normal gather/build

Cons:
It took them three years to get where they are now, so progress is a little slow, but it is there


When all is said and done, I would say to grab a copy of this. If you are worried about the price then just wait until there is a sale to see if it goes on sale on Steam. Otherwise I still think it is worth the price in its current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Looks to be quite the promising game: a mix between Warcraft and Banished, where a humorous and engaging game is displayed in a dynamic (where present) cast and impressive amount of customisation of each individual character-but it sure is taking ages to come along with finishing the content and fixing its bugs; an example being the upgrade options that lead to nowhere... or the catapults that after firing a single shot play a continuous annoying loop noise until you want to delete the game out of frustration.
*sigh*
I seriously want this game to work, because although it has it's problems (being somewhat permanently in it's developing/early access phase) it still is a mad game and I expect will continue to improve to be even better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I decided to give this game another try to see how the progress is, and I have to say I am VERY disappointed with it so far.

It feels like to me its another Age of Empires 3 game with fresh coat of The Settlers 7: Paths to a Kingdom paint on it. In my first review it had it unique idea of being the ultra medival sandbox game of decade that Stronghold 3 should of been. But no instead we're given this while the game is 70% done so far.

Here's what I don't like, to get straight to the point:

-The music has changed from a nice and soft melody to a bland and boring soundtrack
-The UI is small and clunky that even trying to change the size of the UI makes it feel too big.
-The Gameplay resembles a lot of AOE 3 (which isn't a bad game but it wasn't a good game either).    To be more specific its VERY VERY SLOW at the start for its sandbox mode.
-Graphics seem to be dated and ashy gray; it looks like it took a step backwards than when I first purchased the game in July 2013.
-Development of this game is crazy slow. I bought the game when it was around 25-30% complete (Estimating).

I don't like it. I'm not impressed and I'm disappointed at where this game has gone.

Early Access Review

Where are the RPG elements?.. let alone fully explorable building/dungeon interiors and an adventure-focused RPG component"?..

Right now this seems to be just a city builder with an overly elaborate food system (several different types of food that give you satistfaction bonuses if you present a diverse
date: with different options for how to provide them
recommended:
but apparently you should totally build out all of them and use them all because the tutorial said so.

but! there *is* (in some configurations) this totally separate hero dude whom you can make walk around and kill things when you are bored of waiting for villagers to do stuff. And he gains levels for killing stuff! and then you can choose to assign a skill point! SO that's an RPG element I guess?.. until he inevitably dies from clunky controls (and OP poison) and you discover that you can also send hordes of villagers to do the same thing if you really want.

Meanwhile for a resource management game
hoursPlayed: it does not give me nearly enough tools or information to 'debug' my resource flows. Made me appreciate Prison Architect that much more for its great tools for both micromanagement (e.g. following a prisoner/set of prisoners around and actually being able to discern bottlenecks) and macro summaries."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Folk Tale Review
Folk Tale is a game that combines elements from a wide spectrum of genres including RTS, citybuilder, simulation, and RPG in order to bring gamers a totally new and unique experience. The game is still in Early Access and it already has an incredible history. I first began tracking this game during its successful Greenlight campaign. It reminded me of a modern take on The Settlers series but I was hesitant to jump on board until I could see whether it would follow the same path as so many of its predecessors or perhaps it would offer us something new. And it has.

When Folk Tale originally applied for Greenlight status on Steam, it was planned to be a typical RTS citybuilder simulation with a full-length player campaign. And while many of the features had yet to be fleshed out, the core game structure was already in place. In order to give themselves the greatest chance of funding success, the game developers at Game Foundry decided to ask the Steam Community what they wanted to see in this game and an eventual Community Poll determined that most wanted to see Folk Tale as a sandbox game. I can't recall any other time when a game's development was halted mid-stream and completely shifted in a different direction based on our opinions. But here we are. The team from Game Foundry strapped in and accepted the challenge.

This has lead to some timely delays in the game's production and the developers have unfairly caught a lot of criticism for not releasing a finished product yet. Keep in mind, this is the game we decided on and they are doing their best to give us what we asked for even though it added a lot more work for them.  There are still a ton of cool features they plan on adding to this game and they are very active in its production, providing constant updates and weekly progress blogs to keep us informed every step of the way. The game is already in a stable, playable state though. So getting the game now is not a bad idea. And, because the developers are so open and active with the Community, you could possibly help shape part of the game's future.

But what can you expect from Folk Tale right now? For starters, the graphics for this type of game are very rich and full of vivid detail. There is a fully-rotational 3D camera that operates smoothly and easily. The user interface is in place and functional, although many of the mouseover tooltips are still missing. Its not too difficult to figure out what each button does though. A majority of the sound effects and voiceovers are now finished. Most all of the buildings and economic/resource elements are in place and functioning properly. Multiple maps are available for play and editor tools have been included already so the Steam Community can already begin working on their own custom additions. The mobs of creatures have been released into the wild and will offer a bit of a challenge during your otherwise tranquil building experience. Loot and treasures can be gathered after defeating enemy threats, which can be used to equip your villagers and troops with better armor and such. A lot of research and upgrades have been added to the game already, but even more is on the way.

Many of the planned features are still being developed though. Building upgrades have not been implemented as of yet. Eventually, heroes will be added into the mix but are not available at this time. The villagers and troops have abilities and skill points to be distributed as they gain experience, but currently this feature is not working. All of the villagers still share the same facial image in the user interface when selected. Other units are expected to be added in the future as well (wizards, for example). And since changing from a story-driven campaign to a sandbox style of play, there is no longer a tutorial to get players started. I believe one will be added fairly soon, and if not, I strongly urge the game developers to consider including one in order to familiarize new players with the basic concepts of the game. While I thoroughly enjoy the game already, it is quite clear that there is still a lot of work to be done. If you're one of those players who are only interested in finished products then you might be waiting on Folk Tale for a while.

The Good:
=======+  Rich and highly detailed graphics
+  Quality sound and voice acting
+  Fully-rotating 3D camera w/smooth controls
+  Variety of buildings and research
+  Well-designed economy and resource structure
+  Extremely mod-friendly w/editting tools included
+  Varying difficulty to offer greater challenge
+  Save game feature implemented and working
+  Friendly and active game developers

The Bad:
======-  No tutorial included
-  No skirmish options or goal-oriented features
-  While stable, there are still a few bugs
-  Mouseover tooltips only half-complete
-  Many features still not implemented or under development

Final Thoughts:
===========Folk Tale is still a long way from completion, but is highly enjoyable already. The team at Game Foundry laid out plans for a game that will offer a multitude of exciting features and they continue to work diligently trying to make it a reality. If they continue down this path then Folk Tale is sure to be a strong candidate for GOTY (whenever its fully released). For those who enjoy real-time citybuilding simulations, I'd encourage you to go ahead and buy the game now since its fully playable. Those who are impatient and only want to experience finished products should add the game to your Wishlist and wait for completion or else you will most likely have a negative experience given the game's currently un-finished form.

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you ever wanted to take a city building sim to the next level and actually have a hand in the individual lives of it's occupants, Folk Tale actually delivers. Folk Tale came across my screen one day and I was very impressed by it's intended scope so I immediately purchased it in early access. It's been a year since then and I can honestly say this game has come a long way. It's an incredibly ambitious game. No other city sim comes close to the complexity of strategy and rpg elements as Folk Tale in my opinion. It's beautifully rich in detail in respect to both graphics and game play. It fills a depth nitche that was absolutely missing in Banished. Having each individual in your village have a character sheet and equipment can feel a little overwhelming at first, but once you become familiar with how the game is played it's much easier to manage. I can honestly say I never expected this game to get here. It's worth every penny and then some. If you like city builder and rpgs you HAVE to give this a try. There is truly nothing else like it. While it's still a ways out from completion, the potential for greatness is OBVIOUS! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Folk Tale, in short, has a  ways to go.

In long, I would like to be able to play the campaign. But, quests are ridiculous, you can finish them and save, then when you load the game to play again, the same quest is there to be completed again. Its so nice to finish quests, looting chests to find armor/weapons that only fit your main hero, but are worse than the base armor/weapons. Whats the point of that?

Stone takes forever to get, every other material seems to stack up fast, but not stone. Then when you finally get enough stone to build something, you get raided by some crazy half-animal warriors, and your 3 city guards aren't enough to defend the city while your one hero is out trying to complete quests you'll have to complete again. And science forbid that your barracks gets attacked (because it will be destroyed in seconds, like every other building) building hitpoints are based on lego models, and the developers must have shot at them with guns to see how fast they'd be destroyed.

The game just needs some simple fixes to the basic mechanics, and needs more help with other aspects, such as heroes, and city guards. Also, using two inventories to equip characters with armor/weapons is annoying. Plus, I want it to be easier to find each type of worker.

I'll update this review as I continue playing updates. At the moment, don't buy this game for full value, or even... 20% off (which is what drove me to buy it) The game has promise, it reminds me of Fable, which is fun, but just needs help.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wish i hadn't paid money for this.

and I really do not like leaving bad reviews for all the hard work people put into games

It had lots of things i love but grew to hate this oh so quickly

i loved stronghold, many 3rd person clickies, kingdom management and put them together for joy you say?... oh no

your hardened peasants are pathetic, warm, well fed and protected would have kept many of the medieval peasants happy not in this, if they are not wearing a brand new t shirt and have a pint in their hands they will jump ship at the first opportunity.. and not just a general malaise unhappiness seriously kicking the dog and throwing the toys out of their pram unhappy.

this started the downward spiral, the adventure type missions pigeon hole a champion character in to an instance, slow and clumsy and far too easy

I know all too well this is an EAG and things need to be ironed out but they have started on a very unsatisfying gaming experience which means it i really has a ton of work to do

Equipment should be taken automatically by the peasants when available unless you state otherwise.
Indicators for what and who is available for work, and peasants while not doing anything form around a single point
wall building broken into towers and walls
when you group by ctrl and number camera to flick to group
enemy spawn is just annoying
viewing distance is far too small
unhappiness in village goes from manageable to everyone has left in seconds
inventory does not need to show so much wood etc a store bar at the top is good enough
market place is a wtf is going on experience you can and cant buy certain things?

i cannot put my finger on it but this is should be a good game but it really isn't

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had purchased this game at release and I was excited for a quirky, funny town builder.  This game has changed, embarassingly so, and has moved in a completely different direction.  The original plan for this game was clearly trashed and the developers adapted a cookiecutter sandbox idea.  It's been done 10,000 times before so why not one more?  Tired idea for a tired genre.  The graphics are also years behind.  I know this is an indie game but no one needs a 2/10  early 2000's town builder.  Do not buy.  Your money can serve you better elsewhere.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nImagine if Banished and Warcraft 3 had a love child, it was so beautiful and they both swore to love and take care of it. Then they took one look at it, threw up all over the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, andsent it to The Wall, to serve out the rest of its digusting, crap life, plagued by the free-folk
date: White Walkers, and the knowledge that they will never have hair as great as Jon Snow.\n\nI have rarely ever given a game a thumbs down. I usually find some sort of saving grace in a game. I purchased this quite some time ago, I attempted to play it and the tutorial was so dry and uninspiring so I gave up on it. Fast-forward a few months later I really get the urge to play this game. I re-install it, and decide to opt out of the tutorial and dive into the game. It's good at being simple enough to not need to really look at instructions or a guide/tutorial. However the game is borderline TOO SIMPLISTIC. Half the items you click on say: THIS HAS NOT BEEN IMPLEMENTED YET." The other half
recommended: that do work are filled with so many bugs that you want to cry.\n\nThere are barely any sound or visual cues
hoursPlayed: the game doesn't do a good job in telling you when your town is under attack
voteText: there is one sound cue "YOUR BASE IS UNDER ATTACK." However it only happens after somebody pretty much already dies. Visually many of the creatures are so tiny that even when you watch your town
helpfulPercent: you have not a clue that there's a god damn spider killing people.\n\nMy Windmill was glitched out the ♥♥♥. It rendered 3 townsmen as "ghosts
votesHelpful:
as in they were there, not clickable, but weren't farming. The tier 1/3 walls make no sense, there's no cost on them, yet they do take resources and I calculated how much it would be for the wall, but when I built one section it refused to let me build any other walls on the entire map. I tried everything to fix this.

This game may have potential, if it were 2008. The whole concept seemed cool, but the developer's take on it is so dated. To re-address my previous point, they combined two great games. The RPG elements of Warcraft 3, and the town building experience of Banished, but they somehow managed to only take the awful parts of both games, making this probably the worst experience I've ever had playing a city builder."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIts been 1 year since I last wrote a review of this game.  At the time I was very angry about a lot of things.  first being the fact that shortly after backing it.  I found myself un-able to play it at all.  Last week after the patch 0.3 I got my first crack at actually playing the game and walking thru the in game tutorial.   I was shock!  Finally I could understand and play the game with easy.  No more broken basic needs.  Or at least I didn't encounter any.  Last year I would not recommend this game to anyone.  For fear of losing a friend.  The game was so flustrating.  Most of the common stuff was broken or not even there at all.   Today I found it playable and while I think the game progression is rather slow.  I am happy to say its been worth the wait.   I feel a lot of folks will not know what to do with this game though.  Do you play it like warcraft 3 build a economy and conqueer X enemy?  Not so much.  Its more on the lines of Banish I think.  Like a sim settlement builder type of thing.  In the near future that will probably change with heros, and dungeons coming in to play.   I would recommend this on 2 things.  First they dev's have a monthly blog supporting the up comming ideals and fixs, and second its fun to play.  Don't take my word on it.  Get out there and give it a try!  Write your own view and claim the New world for your villagers!  Woohoo!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo I deleted my first review because it was a year old. Read what I just wrote... A YEAR OLD! Do not waste your money on this game at this time. The game is at 45% complete in 15 months. At this pace it will be almost 3 years before completed. Yes, there are others who will argue that the the game is in beta and that they do a very nice job writing and providing updates about every idea and concept they have. If they spent half the time coding as they do explaining what the final product will be the game would be finished. These are rookies, period! They are using our money to attempt to create a game that I will admit has an interesting concept and fresh approach.  That being said, ideas and concepts does not make a playable enjoyable game. If they do finish this project the game will be one that I play but they do not need anyone else's money until they show more value for the money some of us already spent. 15 months to reach 45% Are you kidding me?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It seems like most of the negative reviews are from people dissapointed that the game switched directions.  I do understand their feelings.  However,  when this game first launched on steam, in the early access description box, the developers clearly stated that they where going to take the game where the fans wanted it to go.  A majority of the customers wanted a sandbox game and that is what we are getting so it is not fair to down vote this game when you knew it would change throughout development!

The game is coming along nicely although progress is somewhat slow.  If you're looking for a city building game with RPG elements, free building placement and some humor I would definitely reccomend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have had this since the Early Release Edition and I finally got to see the end results of waiting. First the Pro's: Easy to learn reminds me alot of Age Of Empires where you collect resources. Reminds me of Colonization where settlers come over when you are doing good:) I went and tried the tutorial and it helped me with 90% of the game.  You can assign any inactive to any job & you can change them up.Now the Con's You really have no way of knowing how many peasants are inactive until you want to build and there is no way you can call them over to any 1 spot where you can assign them tasks. Also you really can't tell how your research is going accept that it tells you when you are done. Unlike Civ series where it tells you how many turns left to get to your ending reseach.

Over all it feels like Civ series but on a smaller scale. With a little more work it could be a Fun  game without the frustration you may feel from time to time. Is it worth the asking price maybe. Depends how you like the Civ Series:)
Overall I would give the game a 8 out of 10. Nothing more then that though at this time:)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFolk Tale is a game that really needs some professional TLC.  It has many promising features but is riddled with bugs, lack of polished content and some serious gameplay mechanics issues.  For something that has been in early access for over three years, I'm surprised more hasn't been done here.  For every time i found something that made me love the game, I found three other things that made it a chore.  Games should be about enjoyment and Folk Tale isn't there yet.  Maybe in another three years?  If we are still here.  My recommendation: wait until final release and then decide based on features/reviews.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yesterday i bought this promising game, but i regret spending my money on something which is merely a demo. Other people have described the flaws in detail, like no upgrade options, no research and a buggy menu with hollow buttons.

I really hope that the devs are not going to abandon this project and use the money the launch a whole different game, since patches are slow.

Only consider buying this DEMO if you believe in supporting a nice idea for a citybuild/RPG game.

My advice: DON'T BUY IT, THE GAME IS NOT FINISHED BY FAR. You'll feel sorry like i do after only 9 hours of buggy gameplay for $25.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been watching this game for a long while and finally decided to puchase for play. Nice demo vid, but most things don't work/exist. impementing any kind of army with descent stats not capable, no defensive buildings, which is okay so far as the enemy A.I. is too low to matter, but predators will decimate your population just as well. tough keeping the people happy once the town is large enough, because like the army a lot of things don't work. It would be key to be able to upgrade significant structures...
All in all it looks good but fails to perform. It doesn't seem to be going anywhere, and this is too bad. the game is much like a modern version of warcraft with a differant face on it, more plesant and wider in scope, if it ever gets out of second gear (of a five speed), i'm not holding my breath at this stage...
Maybe i could recommend the game if i saw some major improvement, but not yet...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So...People have said it already. I'll say it again. But instead of retyping this, I want you to imagine the following two scenarios:

You decide to make a cake. That's pretty simple - add some dough, and some sweet stuff, and you've got a cake. Right.

Well, what kind of cake do you want to make? Chocolate? Vanilla? Who knows? Depends on who will be eating it, right? Right? Well, let's go ask those people.

But wait! We can make a bigger cake! A better cake! A cake that everyone will love! So we will now have a chocolate / vanilla / starwberry / cheese / ice cream cake baked in a god damn oven but the chilled in a freeze and oh god we really don't know what we any more other than making everyone happy so here is a big pile of burnt cake, melted ice cream, mouldy cheesecake andf you can dig through it and try to find something you like.

Welcome to Folk Tale. This game started witha  tons of promise. It has since veered of course...and I'm not sure what this game is going to wind up being. I voted for it on Greenlight, I was really excited for it when it came out on Early Access and did something almost as dumb as sticking my gentleman's sausage in a drawer and slamming it fully ♥♥♥♥. I believed that the developers would stick to their original vision and deliver the game they said they set out to make.

Ahahaha. Aha. Aaaahahaha. Yeah. Nope.

This game is one of the many reasons why I no longer buy into Early Access - I've seen them do this exact kind of thing too many times, which is a shame. I love this style of game. I've player Settlers since Settlers two, I've played the Anno series, Sim City series - any kind of management / city buidling game, I really look forward to. It is an underserved market, and Folk Tale had the potential to be really cool.

But then, the devs threw their vision out the window to try to appease to everyone (I mean, sandbox games are the hip thing now, right? Right?! Everyone loves sandbox! So hip! So cool! Like beards and old bicycles and plaid...yeah.)

Basically, this is going nowhere. It has been in Early Access for A Very Long Time". I really don't know what's going to come out of it
date: but I can't recommend anyone buy this until it's done and released - at which point
recommended: you might at least have a chance at knowing what you're buying.\n\nF*@*!* Early Access."

Since this is during a sale, I feel it's the perfect time to state my opinions on this game.

Don't get it. It's more Early Access trash, is never coming out, and is still in what I would rather call a Pre-Alpha than Alpha two years in. Booted it up multiple times offline, never any real changes.

The community for this game is disgustingly delusional, their defense force downvotes any negative reviews, and go so far to say that any critics of the insanely slow dev time are A. Trolls or B. (And this one requires some actual mental gymnastics) that the accounts were stolen by hackers to put bad reviews on the game from accounts that had owned it.

If the lack of development isn't going to put you off the game? Check the discussion wall. See what the people who DO like this game are like. Then run away.

Early Access Review

Half a year ago when I bought this game it looked, smelled and felt like a home-run. However, in the past half year the game has only really seen minor bug-fixes and a save function being added, which leaves me fearing that this game will never go beyond the alpha stage.

If you love a good sim game with a bit of rpg thrown in the mix, keep an eye on Folk Tale. It might become the next great sim-game. However, as of now I would not recommend this game. For me it has thus far been 17€ to play 3 hours of bugged tutorial.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Folk Tale has been one early access game that at the moment I can say is really how all early access games should be made. The communication between the developer and the community is fantastic to say the least, probably the best I've seen yet. The game itself goes through regular substantial updates that actually add real content to the game (surprising I know). Even though right now the game has plenty of content to play and enjoy, especially with the recent 3.0 update, every update moves the game forward to being better and better. The game is great now and I honestly cannot wait until it's finished and is an amazing game!

*Edit* And to all the reviewers stating that this isn't the game they bought 2 years ago" or that "I thought it would be a story but they took that all out for nothing"
date: these developers (unlike many in early access) actually put forward a choice to their community. They set up a survey for everyone to take to get their input on the direction the game should follow http://blog.gamesfoundry.com/2014/05/folk-tale-player-satisfaction-survey.html and really listened to those who were playing the game. SO all these people complaining here
recommended: this wasn't the devs who suddenly felt the need to take out your favorite part of the game
hoursPlayed: it was the community saying it wanted more sandbox and village management over story. How can you blame video game developers for wanting to please the people who actually play their video game?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After having my opinion shrouded by the forum moderators a couple of times and by the fanatic community it self, I've decided to voice my opinion here. This game is far from ready. Having bought this game within the first couple of weeks of its release I am appalled by the lack of progress and content that has been added to this game. Being released over 16 months ago and having little to none progress to show for it, I feel like I've been utterly ripped off. The game is not ready and is a long way to go before completion. The dev state that this game is 46% playable in its current state, a state which is missing a core component of its gamely. Sandbox mode. The only update I've seen happen in the last year is a slummy map and character editor being added to the games content. A feature which is utterly useless considering you cannot play the game at all. The only feature which you are able to access is the tutorial mode which has a buggy save system. The idea for this game is rather good, which was one of the main reasons which compelled me to buy this title in the first place. Even though I am fully aware that this game is an INDIE title in the ALPHA stage, I am utterly appalled by the lack of progress and at the same time amazed by how well the developers are doing. Constantly updating their blogs and making new videos and moderating the forums. Maybe if they spend less time on the forum and editing their blogss and videos and more time on the game, we would see some progress.

Do not buy

-A

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR not worth the price, large scope slow updates, half finished implementations

22/01/2016 Update

If its any indication I brought a game called Crashlands and  played that the same amount of hours in a week that I have played this game in 3 years and that comes down to playable content, there is just not enough in this game.

No updates still in the same condition as months ago. So much promised content but nothing works when implemented the scope for this game has just grown out of proportion.

Always hopefully and after so long in EA I figured surely by now they would have some semblemence of a nearly complete game.
Unfortunately this is not the case. While that have added in a small questline, the issue is that it is very small and also buggy. Buttons still don't work.

Progress on this game is so slow, the developers seem to spend more time writing long blogs about the changes they are making vs actually working on the game.

Not worth the price.

Update 28/3/15

after leaving this game for up to 6 months i figured the devs would have had time to flesh it out a bit. Sadly it is still fill of broken features, now there all these shiny new buttons that dont actutally work.

The game has a small amount of playable content but with no real direction and alot of the features still not working it gets boring pretty quick.

Very slow development. I would still not recommend.

Previous review from about June 2014:


At first glance this game looked really enjoyable the tutorial was fun and and interesting with a little bit of everything.

you got to start building a town and learn what the different buildings did, you got to make an army and go on a action filled adventure killing all sorts of monsters. The tutorial introduced a game I thought I could really get into.

Sadly the actual game is nothing like the tutorial. Currently there is only a broken sandbox mode, half the buttons don't work, the controls are different to the ones you use in the tutorial so you have to learn what the new ones are. With the majority of the building and character controls, even menus not working the sandbox mode is very limited.

The tutorial is misleading and suggests the game is something it is not.
The development is slow and all around sandbox.

Not worth the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So this game appeared to be in development for a very long time. I saw many negative reviews and at the time of writing this the general feeling of the game was mixed. - I gave in anyway and thought i would give it a shot.

Almost immediately i regretted my choice and would have preferred to have spent my money on something else.

The game itself is unfinished and still contains the simplest issues e.g villagers having a female name and voice, but a male picture in its portrait. The gameplay is slow and boring and the AI is extremely stupid. I would not recommend this game to anybody in its current state.

That being said - i would say that this game has a huge amount of potential and it will be something i will keep looking back on in future to see what improvements are made. It has apparently taken over 2 years for it to get to this state however - so im not holding my breath for a miraculous turnaround anytime soon.

3/10 - Would not recommend.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has been released on early access for over a year and a half and it barely has enough functionality to be considered a level editor.  The tutorial seemed like it had promise and the videos seemed cool.  Until you play it and realize every single scene in the video is in the first hour of gameplay.  Then you get to sandbox mode.  A couple buildings and tier 1 units, and of course no storyline, because its sandbox mode. It is missing a lot of basic functionality, the controls are clunky and sensitive, there is very little guidance toward what needs to be done and with the small selection of units it takes a couple hours to play through the entire content available.  Which sums up to a level editor with some basic testing ability.  The early access terms say that it is intended for games a few months from completion so devs can get some help to clear that final hurdle.  This is more like a kickstarter where they haven't done much of anything and want you to pay them to work on it anyway.  I saw this game summer of 2013 and figured I'd wait and see how it progresses, and over a year later I decided to give it a shot.  I cringe to think of what was available last year and I cringe even further to think of the damage this does to the early access program.  I would say you shoud buy this game if you want to support early access, but that won't apply for another two years.  Once the devs get this game to be within 6 months of a decent release, then I would support that statement.  For now I would say stay away until at least 2016.  By then it may be in a beta quality state closing on nearly released.  My prediction is that they jumped the gun on their release on steam, will work on it until the initial profits run out, then release a heartfelt statement on why its the communities fault they cant continue development.  Oh yeah, and I only played a few hours before writing this review because thats the amount of time it took to cover all of the content, and the game became nonresponsive and crashed.  So there's that.  On a final note, if this was one guy working between shifts and on weekends I would be much less critical.  For a full development team working full time, on a commitment to build a product they got people to pay for up front, this is unacceptable progress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is not worth it right now, if I could do it over I would not bought into this game. I don't have a problem with how slow the updates are coming out, for me I voted on this game when it was in green lit I liked the vision they had and that's the game I wanted to play. So as soon as it was released I got it. My problem with the game is this is not the game I bought, their vision has changed alot since green lit, mostly because the community wanted the game changed to a sand box game. That's not what this game was going to be, they where going to add a sand box game play maybe at the end of devlopment, now that's all the games about this is not what I paid for. Getting community opinions is one thing & making minor changes is ok I am all for that, but changing the game in the ways that they have changed is not fair to the people who bought into the origanal vision of this game. In time this may be a great game if it's the kind of game you want to play, for me I will have to wait and see. I would wait until it is alot more developed before invisting in this game, who know's what other changes are in store for the future.

Ok I did what Games Foundry asked me to do in the comments. I gave the game another try. Even putting my previous grips aside about them making it a sandbox game first and taking away the story and choices your where going to have to make, I gave it a go.

After spending a couple of hours playing it, I still cant recommend this game. Yes they have added more to the game then just a tutorial. As an RTS you have very little control of the game. You have no lists I cant tell who is doing what and who is doing nothing. I dont even have a way to click and bring all of my gaurds together at one point. In a game like this I need to click on list so I can oversee everything not just click on random buildings to get info for it. The way people move around to do stuff you lose track of who is where and finding them can get faustrating. Just like I want to click on something and bring all none working peasants to a single place so I can look over their stats and decide what to do with them and that cant be done easily if at all.

The game world looks nice and the game runs smooth graphics are nice. For me graphics dont mean much I dont care about eyecandy if I have a good playable game that is fun. Right now it is a good looking game with no real game play and clunky controls without any real way to manage your town.

Sorry I still cant recommend the game and it has nothing to do with the fact it aint the game a bought when it was released. I tried to give it a fair shake anyway and as it stands it still needs alot of work and the player needs to have alot more control of everything.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I honestly don't know what i expected, I read a couple of posts and knew i should have turned away but thought i'd give it a chance.

Your basic sand box game here with a couple of RPG elements, It's a shame to see they turned away from the campaign as i feel this game needed some kind of objective system to keep me generally interested. The whole build it, expand it, improve it and get bored and destroy it all genre is well over done and didn't really needed another title to the list (Let alone an incomplete one). What happened to the days of RTS games!

The community that seem to follow this game are a good bunch and the devs seem to be posting dev blogs now and again so will keep my eyes on this game and hope that it gets finished.

Would i recommend this game? No - The sandbox is their go to and i feel there isn't enough currently in game for the price tag. (Yeah it's alpha blah blah blah)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I only bought in to the Early Access recently, i missed some of the earlier complaints so i can only speak of the game as it is right now, not how it was 12 months ago.

I have to say Folk Tale is looking good. The game is already playable and in the few months i have had it there have been 3 updates, each bringing more options and flesh to the basic engine. This is happening even as the Devs are adding Editing Options and Systems to ease modding.

The game as it stands is already playable to a similar degree as say 'Banished' (build your community and survive) but obviously the intention is to go much further and it is by no means polished enough for release as it is. It will be at least another year in Development i would assume.

As an Early Access is it doing what it is supposed to do; with regular updates, input from the community and system evolution.

If you understand the core concept behind Early Access then it is a recomended 'buy' - if not, 'wait' but put it on your Wish List.

Train hunter, town get's wiped out by bears.
